DOC.HEAD: Leath Looks on 12 Years in House
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Marvin Leath came to Congress from the heart of Texas with a country musician's soul and a banker's sense. But after a dozen years in the House, Leath is calling it quits - frustrated by the ability of an individual congressman to make a difference. ``You see so much written in the media and so forth about people, incumbents, who get these jobs and they never leave and they're an institution,'' said the Waco Democrat. ``...People say nobody walks away from that job. Well somebody did,'' he said. ``And maybe that gives a little bit of faith to people who think the system is so totally corrupt and bad. It really isn't.'' In the early 1980s, Leath was a part of the group of conservative Democrats called the ``Boll Weevils'' that supported a stronger defense and tax reform. But he said defense spending ran amuck under President Reagan and the deficit's growth from $40 billion to more than $300 billion ``deeply distresses'' him. ``Most of the things I hoped to do ... the big issues, we did something about but we did in excess,'' Leath said. ``I really thought the 80s was going to be the decade that was the most critical in the country's history,'' he said. ``Perhaps it was. But I think if you look back on that, I have to think that as a government, we blew it.'' Reagan didn't exert the leadership to make hard choices, Leath said, noting the government wasn't designed for Congress to make laws alone. The hundreds of interests reflected by Congress also frustrate its power, he said. ``You can't expect (Congress) to develop national policy,'' Leath said. ``You've got to have a strong president, willing to take the political risks to solve the problems. Bush is much more prone to do that than Reagan.'' Leath, who made his fortune as a banker in Marlin and Waco, is known as a pretty fair country music crooner and host of a popular annual barbecue. ``You don't see a whole lot of those kinds of parties around here,'' said Rep. Charles Stenholm, D-Texas, who was elected in 1978 from a neighboring district and was also a ``Boll Weevil.'' ``This guy has star potential,'' Congressional scholar Norm Ornstein said of Leath's singing. Leath's friend Willie Nelson has encouraged him to cut an album. But, Leath said, ``I'm a little bit old to go on the country music circuit.'' At 59, Leath is only two years older than Nelson. In Congress, Leath closely followed the problems of the budget and financial industry from a seat on the House Budget Committee. He voted against thrift deregulation in 1980 and argued that crisis in thrifts, banks and insurance companies was caused by lawmakers' ``foolish mistakes.'' ``Those of us who understood what the banking system was, understood why we had some of the rules we had for 50 years. We felt very reasonably assured when you destroyed those things that were necessary foundations, this would happen,'' Leath said. ``But you couldn't get anybody to listen to you.'' Leath will take about $484,000 in leftover campaign funds with him when he leaves. He'll keep some for himself to repay expenses from that first campaign, he said. The rest will go to charity and political candidates. ``I think that gives me a good way to stay involved in the system,'' Leath said. He worried some about leaving constituents in the lurch, particularly while fighting the Army's decision to deactivate one of two armored divisions at Fort Hood in his district. ``You can always say, `I've just got to do another term.' First thing you know, you're a doddering old man,'' Leath said.

New `Star Trek' Goes Where Old Series Never Went
DOC.TEXT: ``Star Trek: The Next Generation'' this week boldly goes where the original series never went. Its 80th episode airs this week. The original ``Star Trek'' ran 79 episodes before it was canceled in 1969 after three seasons. The new version, which premiered in 1987, ranks among the top-rated syndicated series nationwide. Like the original, it was created by Gene Roddenberry. Cast members paid little attention when the momentous 80th episode was filmed in September. But they are aware of the original show's cult status and the burden they carry. The ``Star Trek'' saga ``seems to have affected people's lives over decades,'' said British actor Patrick Stewart, who plays Capt. Jean-Luc Picard on the new series. Stewart, whose children watched the old show, thinks the new one has accomplished something akin to what the original did. ``It has its own mythology, it has, already, a whole series of legends attached to it,'' he said. ``It's a landmark show in that so very few have achieved, in a recreation, or a reincarnation ... the kind of success, and independent success, that this show has achieved.'' The original series, starring William Shatner as Capt. James Kirk and Leonard Nimoy as the half-Vulcan Mr. Spock, has survived two decades in reruns, and most of its cast has reunited for five movies. It endures in the hearts of thousands of ``trekkies,'' many of whom also have warmed to the new show. At $1 million or more per episode, the Paramount Television production is light years ahead of the old show in cost and special effects. The updated Enterprise has recessed lighting, comfy quarters and even a bar. But the basic formula remains: Intrepid spacefarers dealing with moral and political issues that mimic those of our own time. The 80th episode, for example, deals with two cultures locked in a war like the one in Beirut. It airs on various days this week, depending on the market. Stewart's 25 years in Shakespearean theater are put to good use when he walks the bridge of the 24th-century starship, he said. ``Our show is of an epic nature. It's telling grand stories. It's classical in its structure,'' he said. Rumors persist that the cast of the syndicated series will make a movie, or that the casts of the old and new series will do an episode together. Stewart said he knows ``none of that'' but likes the idea of blending the crews. Not to ``would be a little cowardly,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Cities on `Endangered' List Duck, Embrace Designation
DOC.TEXT: A county commissioner was more than a little embarrassed when Williston, N.D., showed up on a list of 10 Western cities threatened with extinction. But officials in some of the other cities reluctantly agreed the description fits. Marlene Eide helped get Williston, a town of 13,000, on the list of cities with economic problems related to federal policies. When the National Association of Counties recently issued the list, it said the cities ``are in danger of becoming extinct because of restrictions on the use of public lands.'' ``I saw that and I about died,'' said Eide, a Williams County commissioner. ``I'm going to have to leave town. Everybody will be so mad at me but I didn't even do anything.'' Williston's tourism industry has been hurt during recent droughts by falling water levels on Lake Sakakawea, part of the Missouri River Reservoir system managed by the Army Corps of Engineers. But extinction never crossed Eide's mind. Others acknowledged their towns belonged on the list. ``We are in trouble,'' said Audrie Clifford, mayor of Reserve, N.M. ``The traditional means of livelihood in Catron County are cattle and timber, and both are severely threatened.'' The county association said limitations on public land uses in recent years have hurt the communities' economies and severely strained their ability to provide needed services. ``These communities, and there may be hundreds of others like them, are suffering,'' said Michael Stewart, president of the Washington-based group and a commissioner in Salt Lake County, Utah. Also on the list are Weed and Cima, Calif.; Jarbridge, Nev.; Escalante, Utah; Walden, Colo.; Horseshoe Bend, Idaho; Columbia Falls, Mont., and Mill City, Ore. Larry Naake, executive director of the County Supervisors Association of California, said the list is meant to get the attention of the Bush administration and Congress. ``There needs to be more balance between state and federal policies ... between environmental and human concerns,'' he said. Like many of the cities, Weed, a town of 3,000 on the slopes of Mount Shasta volcano in northern California, depends on the timber industry. ``No one wants to come to the city if they have no guarantee they will make a living there. We are just trying to make it, hold on to our city in a beautiful area,'' said Mayor Kalvin Vanderhoof. Mill City was established in 1947, when the timber industry began expanding rapidly in Oregon to build houses for the postwar baby boom. About 50 miles southeast of Portland, Mill City has 1,500 residents. ``People here are frightened,'' said Mayor Mary Smith, who is a secretary for Frank Lumber Co. ``There are more and more reports of mills cutting back, laying people off. If it continues, they're going to panic.'' ``We're a timber town,'' she said. ``There's nothing else here for us.'' Two environmental groups took issue with the inclusion of Horseshoe Bend on the list. The Wilderness Society and Idaho Conservation League officials deny that environmental restrictions on timber cutting in Idaho have hurt the logging town 30 miles north of Boise. ``In 1989 the timber harvested in Idaho was at the highest level in the past 10 years,'' said Mike Medberry of the Idaho Conservation League. ``If Horseshoe Bend is an endangered town, it's not due to lack of timber.'' In Reserve, with fewer than 400 residents, the mayor said the city won't ``dry up and blow away.'' ``I feel the people of Reserve will find a way to exist somehow,'' Clifford said. ``We're tough and stubborn people - survivors.''

DOC.HEAD: Mexico Prepares for More Trade With New Bridges, Improved Roads
LaserPhoto MO1 Oct. 23.
DOC.TEXT: Mexico is building seven border bridges and thousands of miles of highway to handle the boom in traffic from an expected free-trade agreement with the United States. With help from private investors, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari set a plan in motion last year to improve Mexico's inadequate roads and customs system. Solidarity Bridge and border crossing at Colombia, now a cinder-block town of only 350 people, is the largest project. A 66-mile highway linking Colombia to an improved road between Laredo, Texas, and Monterrey will cut the driving distance between the border and Monterrey to 140 miles from 180. More than 2,480 miles of highways are to be built before the president's six-year term ends in 1994. Half will be financed through private investment. The other bridges, under construction or planned, will be in Matamoros, Nuevo Laredo and Valle Hermosa, all in Tamaulipas state; Piedras Negras and Ciudad Acuna in Coahuila, and Ciudad Juarez in Chihuahua state. Mexican officials say the improvements are needed to strengthen trade links with the United States and compete with the economic blocs of Europe and Asia. Trucks crossing into Mexico often must wait for hours, then negotiate undivided, two-lane highways riddled with potholes. ``We don't need to be a rich country to have good roads, but we need good roads to become a rich country,'' said Carlos Joaquin Vallejo Rivero. He directs the state highway office in Nuevo Leon, the northeastern border state where the Colombia project is being built. ``It costs more and takes more time to transport things via bad roads because of higher insurance and loss of goods,'' he said. Trade with the United States took off in 1986 when Mexico joined the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, lowering import duties on hundreds of foreign products and making exports of Mexican manufactured goods a priority. From less than $30 billion in 1986, two-way trade rose to $52 billion in 1989. Mexico is the third-largest U.S. trading partner, after Canada and Japan. A U.S.-Mexican trade agreement that would remove tariffs and other barriers is under discussion. It may be linked with the similar U.S.-Canadian pact of 1988 to create a single North American trade zone of 335 million people. Salinas and President Bush are to discuss the proposal at a meeting Nov. 26-27 in Monterrey. ``All indications are that we are going to have even more intensive trade with the United States, and we are just not prepared,'' said Antonio Fuentes Flores, director of the Trust for the Development of Nuevo Leon. Fuentes, whose organization is overseeing construction, said the 820-acre Solidarity site will include an eight-lane bridge, storage terminals, refrigerated warehouses and hotel. It will more than triple the size of Colombia, a town 10 blocks square populated mostly by farmers. Many people didn't think a new bridge was justified ``because we already had a crossing at Laredo,'' Fuentes said. Laredo is the United States' biggest inland port of entry, with 1,600 trucks crossing daily. ``But we looked at projections of how much traffic would increase in the next few years,'' he said, and ``concluded that we didn't need to just build a bridge, but we needed to build a new concept of border crossings.'' Nuevo Leon was an ideal site, Fuentes said, because more than half the merchandise moving south through Laredo goes to Monterrey, the state capital and Mexico's leading industrial city. Monterrey businessmen wanted a border crossing in Nuevo Leon so they would not have to send products through Nuevo Laredo in Tamaulipas state. They claim customs officials and corrupt unions in Nuevo Laredo inflate the cost. The Mexican side of the bridge and its support facilities is to cost $49 million, split between the federal government and private investors. Laredo, Texas, is financing the U.S. side, at $62 million, with help from the state government and Washington. The site is Dolores, a town 18 miles from Laredo. Four new highways in Nuevo Leon, totaling 350 miles, are being built with $584 million in private funds. Vallejo of the state highway office said the concessionaire, Viaductos de Peaje, would charge tolls for 8 to 14 years before turning the roads over to the state. He said the highways would be divided, with at least two lanes in each direction, speed limits of 75 mph, lights in urban areas, rest stops and the concession company's own roadside mechanics and patrolmen.

DOC.HEAD: 4-year-old Pioneer Inaugurates Genetic Revolution in Medicine
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: At 12:52 p.m. on Friday, Sept. 14, doctors at the National Institutes of Health began transfusing white blood cells into the tiny arm of a 4-year-old girl with a rare inherited ailment. For 28 minutes she played with her doctors and put stickers on their lab coats as she helped them launch a new era in medical treatment. She became the first person to receive gene therapy, a treatment intended to compensate for the genetic defect she was born with by giving her normal copies of the defective genes. News of the experiment had special interest for Suzanne Tomlinson, a 27-year-old woman from Alexandria, Va. ``The idea of gene therapy was always sort of far off and maybe a little idealistic,'' she said. ``It has been in the back of my mind that, theoretically, gene therapy would be the key that would really cure the disease.'' The disease is cystic fibrosis. She was diagnosed with it when she was 7 months old. The 4-year-old gene therapy pioneer, whose name has been withheld, has a rare immune system disorder. But gene therapy holds promise for people with many inherited diseases, including cystic fibrosis. Indeed, recent discoveries about cystic fibrosis have made it one of the leading candidates for gene therapy, perhaps within the next five years, said Robert Beall, executive vice president for medical affairs at the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation in Bethesda, Md. ``What we thought to be decades away is now years away,'' said Beall. Other potential candidates for gene therapy within the next few years are certain forms of anemia, hemophilia and muscular dystrophy. It will be at least several months before researchers know whether gene therapy is succeeding in the 4-year-old girl. Many researchers, poised to expand the applications of gene therapy, say the experiment represents the historic opening of a new era in medicine. When the experiment was approved in July, Gerard McGarrity, chairman of the National Institutes of Health approval panel, said: ``What we're doing today is adding gene therapy to vaccines, antibiotics and radiation in the medical arsenal. Medicine has been waiting thousands of years for this.'' Tomlinson, too, has been waiting. Her parents have long been active with the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation, and she works there as consumer affairs coordinator. She was married earlier this year and attends law school at night. But she still makes time to follow cystic fibrosis research, including the several-year-long debate over the ethics and risks of gene therapy. The decision to proceed ``shows that society is willing to accept this,'' she said. Criticism of the experiment was important, because ``it makes people think about the seriousness of this work,'' Tomlinson said. Scientists worry that putting new genes into the body could trigger cancer or other problems. And some worry about the ethics of altering human genetic makeup. ``But I don't want to see them (the critics) stop it,'' Tomlinson said. ``I don't want their fear of the unknown to hold us back.'' Last summer, researchers found the gene that is defective in people with cystic fibrosis, and this year they showed that the defect could be corrected in the test tube. The next experiment will be to try to insert the normal cystic fibrosis gene into mice, and then try again in larger animals, such as sheep, Beall said. Then human experimentation could begin. Because the most important symptom of cystic fibrosis is the accumulation of mucus in the lungs, an aerosol spray that delivered genetically engineered cells to the lungs might be all that is required for most patients. Tomlinson has a mild case of cystic fibrosis. She follows a physical therapy regimen every morning to dislodge mucus in her lungs, and she takes enzyme pills with every meal to help digest her food. Several times a year she is treated for lung infections, usually managing to avoid the hospitalizations that many people with cystic fibrosis undergo. ``I've really been able to lead a full life,'' she said. As researchers scramble to finish the preliminary experiments to pave the way for gene therapy in cystic fibrosis, Tomlinson is uncertain what that means to her. Despite her enthusiasm, she isn't sure she'll volunteer to be one of the first to try the new treatment. ``I want to be sure it works,'' she said. ``I used to do more research, but now because there's so much going on in my life, and I'm healthy, I guess I'm more skeptical.''

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Pass Stripped-Down Crime Bill
DOC.TEXT: Congress late Saturday gave final passage to a stripped-down anti-crime bill, avoiding certain fights over such contentious issues as the death penalty and a ban on assault weapons. The House approved the measure 313-1 and sent it to the White House, where it awaited an uncertain fate. The action came after a joint House-Senate conference committee on Friday cut major provisions from the legislation that President Bush had sought. The cutting was aimed at making the measure more acceptable. Among the bill's provisions, however, was one that would toughen penalties for certain white collar crimes including a possible life prison term in some cases involving fraud by savings and loan kingpins. It also calls for increased penalties for offenses committed against children including for the first time making possession of child pornography a federal offense. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh assailed lawmakers for dropping a provision that would have permitted use of the death penalty for new categories of federal crimes. He said the decision of the conferees to drop the death penalty is an ``enormous step backwards in the fight against violent crime'' and ``welcome news only to violent criminals.'' Sen. Joseph Biden, D-Del., chairman of the Judiciary Committee, said he was pleased that a crime bill was passed, but said ``I am disappointed that we were unable to agree on a truly comprehensive bill ... that contains a massive expansion of the death penalty.'' The bill also: -Enacts new procedures to make it easier for child abuse victims to testify in federal courts. -Authorizes a doubling of federal aid to local law enforcement - up to $900 million. -Authorizes a $20 million ``rural drug initiative'' to finance increased efforts by local police and prosecutors in rural areas to combat drugs. Rep. George Gekas, R-Pa., cast the lone ``no'' vote.

Congress adjourned early Sunday after passing landmark budget, clean air and child care legislation, culminating a stormy election-year session. Major civil rights, campaign finance and crime measures were left unfinished as lawmakers headed home for the onrushing November elections. With the bang of the gavel in the Senate at 1:17 a.m. EST, the second session of the 101st Congress adjourned, sine die.

Congress Adjourns Without Extra Money for Resolution Trust Corp.
DOC.TEXT: Congress adjourned for the year early Sunday without providing any additional funding for the agency charged with bailing out failed savings and loan associations. The Senate early Sunday adopted a measure that would have provided $10 billion to the Resolution Trust Corp., but the House did not act on it. The Bush administration had sought as much as $57 billion. Senate Banking Committee Chairman Donald Riegle said that while the RTC should be kept ``on a very tight leash,'' he believed the Congress should not leave without providing money to carry the agency through the next 90 days. Sen. Jake Garn of Utah, ranking Republican on the Banking Committee, called the sum inadequate and said it was ``the absolute minimum'' necessary to keep the bailout agency in business. Both Riegle and Garn said that dealing with the savings and loan collapse would have to occupy lawmakers' attention as soon as they return in January. Sen. Bob Graham, D-Fla., said it would cost taxpayers more money if the bailout agency had to close for lack of funds. The Senate-approved measure, an amendment to the Federal Home Loan Bank Board Act, also contains provisions requiring the RTC to submit ``detailed justification'' to the Congress for future requests for funds. It also ``expresses the sense of Congress'' that the Resolution Trust Corp. should not use taxpayers' money to pay off uninsured depositors in failed savings and loans. Several senators voiced misgivings about the move, and Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, complained that Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady has refused to appear before congressional panels recently to argue for the money. Metzenbaum said the thrift scandal happened because ``during the Reagan administration, they literally said to the savings and loan executives, `Do what you want.'' ``The American people are (eventually) going to be called upon to spend something like $500 or $600 billion'' to pay for the rescue, he said. ``What a shameful tragedy.'' The measure passed the Senate by voice vote. Sen. Robert Kerrey, D-Neb., said at one point that the rescue operation was very unpopular with the American people, adding that ``it might not have a majority'' if put to a roll call vote.

DOC.HEAD: 101st Congress: Squabbles, Scandals and Landmark Legislation
DOC.TEXT: The Congress that adjourned Sunday stumbled, stalled and scandalized but then passed dramatic national policy changes for taxes, the environment, military spending, foreign policy and child care. ``A Congress of significant accomplishment,'' bragged Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine. The history books, making a cold, hard assessment, may agree. But that wouldn't do justice to the raucous and ugly path this Congress took to get there. The latest two-year lawmaking conclave was America's 101st. At the end, lawmakers were referring to it as ``The One Hundred and Worst.'' ``So many of us wasted so much time,'' House Republican Leader Robert H. Michel, R-Ill., said. ``What a horribly poor example of Congress at its best.'' It started with Senate rejection of President Bush's nomination of John Tower for secretary of Defense, because of his reputation as a boozer and womanizer. The House then weighed in with its own ethics scandal, which culminated in the resignations of Speaker Jim Wright, D-Texas, and Majority Whip Tony Coelho, D-Calif. An attempt at a meaningful bipartisan budget deal in the first year collapsed into a nasty, partisan fight over Bush's proposed cut in the capital gains tax rate. The new House speaker, Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., received a black eye when his conservative Democrats sided with the Republicans and passed the plan. Outvoted, Mitchell was able to stop it in the Senate only through a parliamentary blockade. The first session passed a publicly supported federal minimum wage increase, and Bush and the Democrats agreed to end aid to the Contra rebels in Nicaragua. But those and other efforts were overshadowed by the pay raise. Early in the year, Wright tried and failed amid a storm of public outrage to protect former President Ronald Reagan's proposed 50 percent boost in congressional pay. But it wouldn't die. After taking over as speaker at midyear, Foley engineered a compromise: a big salary boost in exchange for no more special-interest money for making speeches. The House approved it; the Senate didn't bite. House salaries, which were $89,500 last year, will soar to roughly $125,000 next January. With only cost-of-living increases, the senators will make just over $100,000. Congress returned this year to resume a slow legislative pace with only mixed results. A new law designed to reduce chances of major oil spills was enacted. The Americans With Disabilities Act, giving new rights to people with impairments, became law. Democrats succeeded in defeating Bush's proposed constitutional amendment to ban flag burning. But the Democratic Congress couldn't override the president's veto of legislation guaranteeing workers six weeks of paid leave for childbirth or family medical emergencies. The 101st Congress never overrode any of 16 Bush vetoes. And the ethics scandals continued. One House member was disciplined and another quit following sex-related charges. In the Senate, a group of lawmakers became known as the Keating Five, all under investigation for their ties to the head of a failed California savings and loan institution. Meanwhile, all efforts to contain the costs of the S&L bailout were proving fruitless. In May, with the estimates of the federal deficit heading for the stratosphere, Bush decided it was time for a budget summit with Congress. Spring turned to summer and then summer to fall without an agreement. The legislative logjam grew as lawmakers awaited the summit results. Mitchell compared the budget to ``a whale in a bathtub,'' crowding out everything else. Major legislation including a historic revision of the nation's clean air laws, federal aid for child care, civil rights, the farm bill, housing, and anti-crime proposals languished. As the leaves began to turn, pollsters noticed that the public was beginning to turn surly at the apparent ineptness of their Congress and their president. Public confidence in the government's institutions plummeted and some lawmakers reported nasty receptions from voters back home. Finally, at the end of September the White House and congressional leaders signed a budget pact calling for a $500 billion reduction in federal deficits over the next five years. Rank-and-file lawmakers, however, rebelled at the 12-cent gasoline tax hike, deep cuts in Medicare subsidies and dozens of other new fees or service reductions. On Oct. 5, the day Congress had been scheduled to adjourn, the House killed the deal in a painful defeat for Bush and the Democratic leadership. Hoping to put the onus on Congress for the failure, Bush let the government shut down for the weekend. From the wreckage, a new package emerged, one less to Bush's liking but still acceptable to him. It had higher taxes on the wealthy, only a nickel in new gas taxes and a lighter hit on Medicare. The Senate gave it final congressional approval on Saturday. And the budget wasn't the only thing to fall into place. At a time in the year when most previous Congresses had already gone home, the 101st Congress began to click. Among the hundreds of bills passed in the final three weeks were: - A new grant program for child care and increases tax credits for low-income families with children in the name of child-care assistance. - The first overhaul of the federal clean air law in 13 years, requiring new pollution controls on automobiles, factories and utilities. - The first major revision of the nation's legal immigration system in 25 years, providing more visas for families and those with special job skills. - All 13 of the annual spending bills for federal agencies, none of which were completed by the Oct. 1 deadline. The net effect: defense spending goes down, while domestic spending increases. - A phase-down of U.S. support for proxy wars in Cambodia, Angola and Afghanistan, and a 50 percent cut in military aid for El Salvador - all designed to steer away from armed conflict and toward diplomacy. - A five-year farm bill designed to contain costs and address environmental concerns. Efforts at passing campaign reform collapsed, as did a vetoed civil rights bill. A hoped-for major crime package crumbled into a washed-out facsimile. But at the end, congressional Democrats declared victory and took umbrage when asked about Bush's campaign to paint Congress as slow and inept. ``We have persevered on a hard, unpleasant, difficult process up to the very week before election, and we're told it's disorderly,'' complained Foley. ``It's courageous. It's heroic in some ways.''

DOC.HEAD: Lioness Escapes Zoo Cage and Kills 3-Year-Old Girl
DOC.TEXT: A lioness escaped from her cage Sunday and killed the 3-year-old daughter of a zookeeper before being shot dead, the Middle East News Agency reported. The 8-year-old lioness escaped from her cage while it was being cleaned and attacked the girl, Asma Abdel-Azim Ibrahim, the news agency said. The agency said the zoo's manager, Nabil Gad Khalil, shot and killed the lioness. The small zoo, located in the southern town of Fayoum, was closed for the rest of the day while an investigation was carried out.

DOC.HEAD: Ugo Tognazzi, `La Cage Aux Folles' Star, Dead At 68
DOC.TEXT: Ugo Tognazzi, a bookkeeper who became one of Italy's leading comic actors and achieved international fame with his role in ``La Cage Aux Folles,''has died of a cerebral hemmorrhage. He was 68. The Italian news agency ANSA said Tognazzi suffered a cerebral hemmorrhage Saturday morning and died late that night. Tognazzi, who first appeared in Italian films in the 1950s, became one of the country's leading screen personalities in the 1960s with his ability to play supporting roles or comic and dramatic leads with equal ability. He was best known in the United States for his role as a homosexual cabaret owner in the 1979 film adaptation of ``La Cage Aux Folles,'' a bedroom farce that was a stage hit. He also appeared in a 1980 sequel to the movie. Tognazzi was born March 23, 1922 in Cremona. Because of the illness of his father, he was forced to go to work at age 15 as a bookkeeper at a salami factory. But he also spent his youth acting on the amateur stage. He made his first movie in 1950 in the film ``I Caddetti of Guascogna (The Cadets of Guascogona).'' He followed that performance with a series of films in the 1950s that made him a popular character actor. In the 1960s, Tognazzi matured as an actor with a series of creative roles in satrical films such as Luciano Salce's ``Il Federale'' (The Fascist), which is still considered one of Tognazzi's greatest films. After his success in ``Il Federale'' and Dino Risi's ``La Marcia Su Roma'' (The March on Rome), Tognazzi met Marco Ferreri, the director who gave him some of his greatest roles. Together with Ferreri, Tognazzi made such films as ``Una Storia Moderna: l'Ape Regina'' (The Conjugal Bed) in 1963, ``La Donna Scimmia'' (The Ape Woman) in 1964, ``Marcia Nuziale'' (Wedding March) in 1966, ``L'Udienza'' (The Audience) in 1971 and ``La Grande Bouffe'' in 1973. He starred in the 1979 comedy ``La Cage Aux Folles'' and appeared in Roger Vadim's film ``Barbarella.'' In the 1970s and early 1980s, Tognazzi also tackled more serious dramatic roles. In 1981 he won the Cannes Film Festival Palme d'Or award as best actor for his role in Bernardo Bertolucci's ``La Tragedia di un Uomo Ridicolo'' (The Tragedy of a Ridiculous Man). A funeral for Tognazzi will be held Tuesday at the church of Santa Maria del Popolo in Rome. He is survived by his wife, Franca Bettoia, and four children.

DOC.HEAD: Eight Killed, 37 Wounded in Black Faction Fighting
DOC.TEXT: Rival black factions battled through the night at a gold mine compound outside Johannesburg, and company officials said Sunday that eight men were killed and 37 hurt. The fighting erupted Saturday evening at a workers hostel on Rand Mines' Harmony Gold Mine in Virginia, 160 miles southwest of Johannesburg, the company said. Officials said they did not know the cause of the fighting, which went on through the night despite attempts by security officers to halt the battles. No additional details were immediately available. About 800 blacks died in factional violence around Johannesburg in August and September. The fighting between supporters of the African National Congress and the Inkatha movement was mostly an extention of their power struggle in the eastern province of Natal. That battle has claimed about 5,000 lives since 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Sultan of Brunei Spends $950,000 on Birthday
DOC.TEXT: The Sultan of Brunei, one of the world's richest men, reportedly spent at least $950,000 on his nephew's ninth birthday party. The Sunday Express said the sultan converted a ballroom at Claridge's in London into a replica of Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles headquarters. An army of workers turned the ballroom into a giant New York City sewer for the party for young Prince Bahar, the paper said. Four men dressed as the superheros, Donatello, Leonardo, Michelangeo and Raphael, mingled with the young guests. A group of luxurious anterooms were transformed into a network of gurglig drains, the paper said. Music was provided by the pop duo Partners in Kryme, who were flown to London to perform their hit ``Turtle Power,'' the newspaper said. Claridge's banqueting staff served pizza in a neon-lit pizza parlor, The Sunday Express said. It did not say what day the party took place. ``It was an incredible sight,'' said one member of Claridge's staff, who spoke to the newspaper on condition of anonymity. The report could not be independently confirmed.

DOC.HEAD: British Embassy Reopens After 18-Month Break In Ties
DOC.TEXT: Great Britain reopened its embassy in Tehran Sunday after an 18-month break in diplomatic relations over the Salman Rushdie affair, the Islamic Republic News Agency reported. At a ceremony, Swedish Ambassador Hakan Granqvist lowered the Swedish flag at the embassy and British Charge d'Affaires David Reddaway hoisted the British Union Jack. Sweden had looked after British interests in Iran during the break in ties, which were restored last month after a meeting between British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd and his Iranian counterpart, Ali Akbar Velyati. Iran is to reopen its embassy in London on Monday. Relations were cut after the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini declared a death sentence on Rushdie, an Indian-born British novelist, in Feb. 1989 for allegedly blaspheming Islam in his novel ``The Satanic Verses.'' Rushdie has been in hiding ever since, protected by British police.

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Letters on S&Ls Missing, OTS Officials Say
DOC.TEXT: Dozens of letters are missing from the special file of correspondence from members of Congress to savings and loan regulators, according to the Office of Thrift Supervision. Most of the letters were written by lawmakers on behalf of constituents who complained about problems in their dealings with S&Ls, such as accounts that were transferred from one thrift to another as the result of mergers. But some letters provide evidence of members of Congress pressing regulators on behalf of S&L operators, some of whom contributed to the lawmakers' political campaigns. There are thousands of letters, all maintained by the OTS and filed alphabetically under the names of the senators and representatives who sent them. The thrift supervision office, the federal agency created by last year's S&L bailout legislation, keeps the letters for its own use and opens them to members of the public by appointment. There is no supervision of people perusing the letters, which are kept in an area of OTS' Washington headquarters that is out of view of agency employees. Nancy Cohen, OTS' director of congressional correspondence, said she is aware of at least one entire file that is missing. Each file contains dozens of letters written by a member of Congress arranged in chronological order. Ms. Cohen declined to say what file is missing or who may be suspected of taking it. The agency has only one copy of each letter in the centralized archives, although individual regulators may have kept their own copies, Ms. Cohen said. ``I know something's missing and it really bothers me,'' she said. ``I think it's real important to the agency'' to make the files secure, she added, saying she has complained about the situation to high-level OTS officials. ``There is a problem; we're trying to address the problem,'' said Robert Schmermund, director of public affairs for OTS. S&L contributions and the role of some lawmakers has become a hot issue in this election year. The escalating savings and loan crisis has made the letter file a sought-after source of information. Reporters have been the most frequent users of the files, but in recent months congressional aides, political consultants and law firms also have looked at them, Ms. Cohen said. ``It's an election year; everyone wants to see their own file,'' she said. People wishing to examine the files are asked to make an appointment and bring with them a letter to OTS making a Freedom of Information Act request for access to files of specific members of Congress. Once there, they are left alone with the files in an area separated by partitions from OTS employees. Users are allowed to photocopy the letters. There is no inspection of bags and cases of people leaving the OTS office. Schmermund said the agency is concerned about the vulnerability of the current system but also wants to continue to give the public quick access to the files. OTS Director Timothy Ryan wants the agency to be ``as open as possible,'' Schmermund said. To obtain other OTS documents, outsiders must use them in the agency's supervised reading room or submit formal Freedom of Information requests that can take weeks to be answered.

DOC.HEAD: Nobutaka Shikanai, Japanese Media Baron, Dead at 78
DOC.TEXT: Nobutaka Shikanai, who built the Fujisankei Communications Group into Japan's largest media company, died Sunday at age 78, the company announced. Shikanai died at Keio University Hospital in Tokyo, according to an announcement from Fujisankei's office in London. He was instrumental in establishing the Praemium Imperiale awards, and his company reportedly paid $2 million to former President Ronald Reagan to visit Japan and attend the first awards ceremony last year. Shikanai was born in Hokkaido on Nov. 17, 1911, and was a graduate of the politics and economics department of Tokyo's Waseda University in 1936. In 1954, with the creation of the Nippon Broadcasting System, Shikanai began building the Fujisankei Communications Group, which describes itself as the world's fourth-largest media conglomerate. Its holdings include the Fuji Television Network, Inc., the newspaper Sankei Shimbun, the Nippon Broadcasting System and record and video companies. In 1989, he transferred the chairmanship of the group to his son and took the title of senior executive adviser. He founded the Hakone Open-Air Museum in 1969 and the Utsukushi-ga-hara Open-Air Museum in 1981. In 1988, as chairman of the Japan Art Foundation, Shikanai announced the formation of the Praemium Imperiale awards for painting, sculpture, architecture, music, and theater or film. The first winners of the $100,000 prizes were conductor Pierre Boulez of France, filmmaker Marcel Carne of France, painters David Hockney of Britain and Willem de Kooning of the United States, sculptor Umberto Mastroianni of Italy, and U.S. architect I.M. Pei. In addition to Reagan, dignitaries at the ceremony included Mayor Jacques Chirac of Paris, former Prime Minister Amintore Fanfani of Italy, former Prime Minister Edward Heath of Britain and former Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany. Shikanai served as director of the organizing committee for the Tokyo Olympic Games in 1964 and vice president of the Winter Olympic Games in Sapporo in 1972.

DOC.HEAD: Attack on Pornography Cloaks Political Struggle
AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: China's aging Marxist ideologues are organizing a renewed attack on reformers in the guise of a campaign against the country's tiny pornography industry. The Communist Party newspaper, the People's Daily, made the connection explicitly Saturday at the end of a five-day anti-pornography meeting called by the party Propaganda Department. Spreading pornography, the paper said, was one method used by hostile foreign forces to undermine China's socialist system and foster capitalism. ``The struggle against pornography is not just a matter of banning a few bad books and tapes,'' it wrote in a front-page editorial. ``It is an ideological struggle between socialist and capitalist ideas, an expression of the class struggle between the proletariat and the bourgeoisie. This struggle is linked to the success or failure of China's socialist cause.'' Anyone reading the People's Daily would think that dirty books and videotapes are hawked on every corner of Beijing. In reality, one has to hunt these days to find anything more titilating than the collected speeches of 86-year-old senior leader Deng Xiaoping. But political debate has taken on strange forms ever since the June 4, 1989 army attack on pro-democracy protesters in which hundreds, and perhaps thousands, died. The real issues, too sensitive to be debated directly, are these: Has the Communist Party lost its moral right to rule? What system can make China peaceful and prosperous if socialism can't? Economics has been the main forum for political struggle. Chinese and foreign sources say debate over the next five-year plan for the economy is so heated they cannot convene a long-expected party Central Committee meeting. At stake is whether China will resume reforms that reduced central planning in favor of free market forces. But one European diplomat said the bottom line is power - who will exercise top authority after the death of Deng, now rarely seen in public. From that viewpoint, attacking pornography makes sense for the conservatives, led by aging revolutionaries Wang Zhen, Bo Yibo, Chen Yun and Deng Yingchao. It enables them to stay on the offensive and fill large portions of the official press with speeches representing their views. Even more liberal-minded party leaders, such as culture czar Li Ruihuan, can hardly oppose a crackdown on pornography, although in a speech applauding the campaign he cautioned against arbitrarily interfering in ``legitimate aesthetic pursuits.'' The campaign also provides a pretext for raiding book stalls and investigating publishing houses. During a similar anti-pornography drive shortly after the protests were crushed, 32 million publications were burned, many for political reasons. Officials say 12 percent of the nation's newspapers and 13 percent of its social science periodicals were closed. ``If the campaign's really anti-pornography it will have no affect on us,'' a Beijing intellectual said on condition of anonymity. ``But if they are raising the banner of pornography to increase repression, then it will stifle all intellectual inquiry. Already, writers aren't writing anything - they've all shut up. There are no new movies or plays or works of any kind.'' Theaters have been reduced to reviving plays from the 1930s by eminent playwright Cao Yu, now 90. In what passes for innovation, one of Cao's plays, a gloomy melodrama about a Shanghai prostitute, is being turned into a musical. It opens next month. ---= EDITOR'S NOTE - Kathy Wilhelm, Associated Press Chief of Bureau in Beijing, has reported from that city for three years.

DOC.HEAD: Two Liberal Democrats Vie for Oakland Mayor
DOC.TEXT: Both candidates in the Nov. 6 runoff election to replace Mayor Lionel Wilson are liberal Democrats. Both are 43. And their campaigns emphasize the same issues: drugs, crime, education. The major difference is where they have worked. State Assemblyman Elihu Harris has represented Oakland in the Legislature in Sacramento for a dozen years, while his opponent, Wilson Riles Jr., is an 11-year member of the City Council. ``I have been in this community working each day to improve things,'' Riles said. ``I know the people. I know the issues up close. ``Where has Harris been? That's the difference between us. I've been here. He hasn't.'' Harris counters that his legislative work has brought change to the city. ``When I saw the Oakland school system was in trouble I sponsored legislation to put an advisory trustee in there to clean up,'' he said. ``Some schools were guilty of mismanagement, nepotism and, in some cases, outright crime.'' The voters, so far, have found Harris' distance from city government more attractive. He got 45.7 percent of the votes in the June non-partisan primary, more than runner-up Riles and the third-place Wilson combined. Riles has narrowed the gap, but the most recent poll, about a month before the election, showed Harris still leading, 43 percent to 35 percent. Wilson was undone in his bid for a fourth term by his support for a failed $602 million deal to lure pro football's Los Angeles Raiders back to Oakland as well as voter discontent over a community battered by crime and last year's earthquake. A city manager administers the day-to-day functions of city government, so the mayor's four-year term is primarily a platform for leadership. Harris plays up that aspect, saying he knows how to get things done and arguing that Riles doesn't follow through on ideas. ``This job is one where you can make a lot of difference,'' Harris said. ``I think I can make a difference. Oakland can do better.'' Riles says the city has been making progress. ``People have already got together to run drugs out of their neighborhoods,'' he said. ``It takes community action to pressure landlords and hold anti-drug rallies. There are many successes.'' But Riles, who has been endorsed by Wilson, concedes his chances could be hurt by his ties to ``old city hall.'' ``There's no question that we're going through a tough time right now and people are looking for change,'' he said. Both candidates pledge to revive Oakland by pushing for outpatient drug treatment programs, an increase in police officers, better school and community anti-drug programs, and economic development. Oakland is known more for bad neighborhoods, crack houses and prostitution than its developing shopping areas, beautiful salty Lake Merritt and championship Oakland Athletics baseball team. The city of 360,000 people sits across the bay from San Francisco, which has twice as many people but about half the violent crime. So far this year, 134 people have been murdered in Oakland, compared with 85 in San Francisco. Last year, Oakland had a record 148 murders and San Francisco had 73.

DOC.HEAD: Parkview Hilton, a Downtown Hartford Landmark, Demolished
LaserPhoto HF1
DOC.TEXT: The Parkview Hilton, a modern-style glass-walled hotel that was just 36 years old, was demolished Sunday after its owners were unable to find a buyer for the vacant building. A festive crowd estimated at 10,000 watched the explosion from Bushnell Park, a sloping green that stands between the hotel and the state Capitol and gave the hotel its name. The 16-story building was imploded - exploded from within so that it would fall on itself - by demolition workers who used 60 pounds of carefully placed dynamite. The first blasts rang out at about 7:30 a.m., and the building was gone within seconds, bringing a rowdy cheer from the crowd. The Parkview had been vacant since Dec. 31 when it closed its doors, a victim of the sagging demand for hotel space in Hartford. The owners of the building, Chase Enterprises, could not find a buyer for the property, and decided to destroy it to make way for something new. The demolition was the second this year in downtown Hartford, where the booming economy of the mid-1980s has given way to a deep economic slump that has halted development. There are no firm plans to develop the Hilton site, but it is one of several Hartford sites under consideration for the new corporate headquarters of United Technologies Corp. ``You hate to see something like that go down. It's still a fine building,'' said Helmut Garbemann, a retired construction worker from Newington who watched the building fall. ``It's a shame. It's too bad the city is dying out like this.'' But most in the crowd seemed drawn by curiosity rather than nostalgia, and the mood was similar to those watching a fireworks display. Scores of people recorded the event on video cameras, waiting patiently in 34-degree weather. ``I've always watched on TV, but this is the first time I've ever seen one of these up close,'' said Edward Danoff of West Springfield, Mass., who took his three grandchildren on the 30-mile trip to Hartford to watch the event. The hotel, built in 1954, was one of Hartford's first modern-looking skyscrapers. Although it was supported inside by concrete pillars, it appeared all steel and glass from the outside. It had been a Hilton hotel since 1966 when the chain assumed full ownership; after Hilton sold the building in the mid-1970s, the hotel retained the name. James Manafort, president of Manafort Brothers Inc., the company that destroyed the building, said it collapsed just as planned, with no complications. ``We've very pleased,'' he said. ``It was a 100 percent shot.'' The same company demolished the Hartford-Aetna Building on April 1. That building was destroyed to make room for new development, despite the objections of local preservationists, who said it was one of the city's oldest skyscrapers.

DOC.HEAD: It's Class Warfare, 1990-Style
DOC.TEXT: ``If you make big money, here's good news,'' opens a fast-talking political commercial from north-central Indiana. ``Candidate John Johnson ... is for lower tax rates for the wealthy.'' And that's not all. ``As a millionaire himself, maybe John Johnson doesn't know how middle-income families are struggling these days,'' the ad continues. ``But Congressman Jim Jontz does. He wants to stop tax breaks for the wealthy and give middle-income families some help for a change.'' Welcome to class warfare, 1990-style. At least that's what Republicans are calling it. Democrats prefer to characterize their latest campaign theme as a quest for ``fairness'' - for the poor and middle-class Americans they say have suffered from a decade of greed and negligence fostered by the Republicans. Ever since the savings and loan scandal broke, Democrats have been putting new emphasis on the theme that they are the party of ordinary people while claiming the GOP cares more about the wealthy. Their job has been eased considerably by the prolonged budget battle and President Bush's public wavering over whether to raise taxes on the rich. Polls show him and many of his party's candidates on a downward slide - and some Democrats already are declaring victory. ``The Democrats have won the fairness issue. It is driving the polls and it will drive the elections,'' said Rep. Beryl Anthony, D-Ark., chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee. ``The president has very clearly staked out territory that his own candidates can't defend.'' Republicans traditionally have an advantage when the political debate is over whether or not to raise taxes, as Bush demonstrated in 1988. But when the issue becomes whose taxes to raise, the edge goes to the Democrats. The GOP position is based on the theory that well-off people, if allowed to keep their money, will invest it and fuel the economy. The Democratic line is epitomized in a commercial made by the national party: ``In the '80s, tax breaks for the rich drove up the deficit while middle-income working families got squeezed. Democrats don't want you to get stuck with the bill again. We're fighting for fairness. Isn't that what America's all about?'' Numerous Democrats are taking their cues from the ad, some even going so far as to borrow its contrasting images of limousines and party-goers vs. farmers and factory workers. The populist refrain has helped revive the Democratic gubernatorial campaigns of Ann Richards in Texas and Tony Celebrezze in Ohio. And it's giving fresh ammunition to embattled incumbents and long-shot challengers in New Hampshire and Kentucky, Iowa and Colorado, Alabama and Washington state. Will the election really come down to a question of fat cats versus working stiffs? Rick Shelby, political director of the National Republican Senatorial Committee, says that's ``an oversimplification of the true facts, but nevertheless something we have to deal with.'' His advice to GOP candidates is to ``oppose taxes and support the elderly.'' Many Republican candidates are, in fact, holding fast to the no-new-taxes position that Bush embraced and then abandoned, even as they try to portray themselves as friends of senior citizens and the disadvantaged. Others are sounding more and more like populist Democrats. ``Unlike some folks around here, I think everyone should pay their fair share, including the rich,'' Sen. Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., says in a campaign ad. Two Republican Senate candidates are criticizing the latest federal budget agreement in the same terms. ``It does not hit the mark of fairness and equity,'' said Sen. William Cohen, R-Maine. ``The vast majority of the money is coming out of the middle class,'' objected Rep. Tom Tauke, R-Iowa. Tauke is facing a full-scale populist assault by Democratic Sen. Tom Harkin. When Harkin ran a rich-poor ad featuring a pyramid of collapsing champagne glasses, Tauke countered with a spot highlighting Harkin's vacation home in the Bahamas. Tauke said he had to do it because Harkin's ``class-warfare ads'' were working. Josie Heath, the Democratic Senate candidate in Colorado, ran into some backlash after running a fairness ad. Heath's ad said a lot of wealthy people got wealthier in the last 10 years and ``they're paying less taxes. And we had the middle class and working people earning less and paying more. That's wrong.'' What Heath didn't mention, analysts noted, was that she and her husband are millionaires. Said one: ``Heath's reference to the wealthy as `they' is dubious.''

DOC.HEAD: Investigator Has Made Bambi's Case `Life's Work'
DOC.TEXT: Private investigator Ira B. Robins proudly describes it as his ``life's work.'' For six years he has risked slander suits, amassed $30,000 in debts and endured ridicule while seeking evidence to reverse the murder conviction of former Playboy waitress and and onetime fugitive Lawrencia Bembenek. ``I so much believe in what I'm doing you couldn't pay me; it's something you have to do from the heart,'' said Robins, 48. ``This is an opportunity that people don't get very often in their lives. ``There have been no days off. Morning, noon and night I'm going to meetings and rally, chasing leads, talking to witnesses or the media.'' Robins, a former police officer, said the volunteer investigation he began in 1984 has left him without a home - he lives in the basement of a friend's house - and without enough money to repair his wrecked car or pay support for his 12-year-old son, alimony to his former wife or back taxes to the government. He also has failed to persuade authorities to free Ms. Bembenek, who was convicted in the 1981 killing of Christine Schultz, the former wife of Ms. Bembenek's then-husband, Elfred Schultz. Ms. Bembenek was sentenced to life in prison. The 32-year-old Ms. Bembenek, popularly known as ``Bambi,'' created a media sensation when she escaped from prison July 15. Canadian police captured her with her fiance, Dominic Gugliatto, 35, on Oct. 17 in Thunder Bay, Ontario. She is awaiting extradition back to Wisconsin. During her murder trial, prosecutors contend Ms. Bembenek was upset about the $700-a-month alimony Schultz had to pay the victim. Robins said he has collected more than 10,000 pages of documents and has interviewed several witnesses who claim the evidence used by prosecutors was faulty. ``The more I got going on it, the more I was convinced there was something wrong,'' he said. Some supporters claim Ms. Bembenek, who was fired from the police department in 1980 for lying about a friend's marijuana arrest, was framed by police because she had knowledge about alleged police corruption. They also note that during her trial, one of Ms. Schultz's young sons testified that the person seen in the house the night of the killing was not Ms. Bembenek. The evidence Robins has released includes an affidavit from a neighbor of Ms. Bembenek that suggest prosecutors' key evidence - the wig believed to have been worn by the killer and then flushed down Ms. Bembenek's toilet - may actually have been flushed by another woman. But police, prosecutors and the courts repeatedly have ruled that Robins hasn't found anything to warrant reopening the case. And some are aggravated with his incessant charges of a coverup. Police Chief Philip Arreola says the portly, bespectacled Robins has acted out of an infatuation with Ms. Bembenek, who also has been a model and calendar pinup. Milwaukee's chief prosecutor says Robins is seeking to profit from a murder case that has gained international attention and become a favorite of tabloid television. Robins denies both contentions, saying his motivation is to seek the justice he believes has been denied. He particularly bristles at the suggestion he's infatuated with Ms. Bembenek. ``I'm not in love with her,'' he said. He said he didn't even meet Ms. Bembenek until eight months after he began his investigation. He said the tens of thousands of dollars he's spent on the investigation was his own money, except for $9,000 he borrowed from friends and $1,800 in donations from Ms. Bembenek's supporters. A police union threatened recently to sue Robins for slander for his remarks to news media, which sometimes have named specific officers involved in the alleged coverup. Robins said he welcomes any lawsuits and will use the ``absolute truth'' as his defense. His critics also have accused him of stirring the debate for his own profit, citing an agreement with Ms. Bembenek entitling Robins to a 25 percent cut on the sale of movie and book rights. Robins acknowledges such an agreement exists and also noted the recent exposure of her case had landed him appearances on several television talk and news shows. Executives at most of the shows said Robins was not paid for his appearances, except for money to cover transportation. But Robins said he hasn't discussed any book or movie deals although dozens of agents have contacted him about selling his rights or representing him in future sales. He said he will one day deserve the proceeds from books or movies - but only after Ms. Bembenek is freed. ``I can't spend the time right now to set up a deal because I have a case to win and I can't stop until justice is served,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Quayle Blast Democrats Who Break Promises on Taxes
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: ``We have to beat a legend,'' the candidate lamented. ``A legend that lied.'' The topic was taxes: the complaint, a broken campaign promise not to increase them. In this case, the promise came from a Democrat who couldn't keep it, and Republicans were making the most of it - ignoring the parallel to President Bush's own tax reversal. In the wrapup phase of the off-year election campaign, there's a battle raging for control of the tax issue. Bush and Vice President Dan Quayle, the high-profile Republican campaigners, are trying to fix blame for the coming tax increases on the Democrats, even though the administration signed on to the budget deal to raise them. The Democrats contend that the issue was fairness, that they had to fight the administration to make sure the wealthiest Americans would pay the biggest share in deficit-curbing taxes. Bush's ritual campaign promise of 1988 - ``Read my lips, no new taxes'' - is long gone, a casualty of his decision last spring to negotiate a deficit deal with the Democratic Congress. The president said he had to compromise. ``Haven't liked that a bit, but I've done it because the president must at certain times put the overall good of the country first,'' he said, campaigning in Irvine, Calif., on Friday. He said the tax medicine had to be taken ``because the Democratically controlled Congress simply has been on an uncontrolled spending binge for years.'' Quayle pressed the argument in a television interview Sunday, saying ``Democrats got taxes, we got spending cuts.'' On the NBC program ``Meet the Press,'' Quayle discounted pollsters and analysts who say there's a Democratic surge, saying that ratings always fluctuate in ``the political silly season.'' He said it's the Democrats who have the problem because ``the American people have had it'' and they're fed up with incumbents. At some campaign stops, the Republican rhetoric sounds as though Bush had never uttered his ``no new taxes'' promise in the first place. That heightened the irony the other day when Quayle campaigned for Daniel Mangini, the Republican candidate for Congress in New Jersey Gov. Jim Florio's old district. Mangini promises to vote against any federal tax increases. The Democratic nominee, Robert Andrews, says he would oppose higher taxes for at least two years. Democrat Florio held the seat for 15 years before he was elected governor in 1989, pledging that he wouldn't raise state taxes. He pushed $2.8 billion in increases through the legislature this year. So the 250 or so people at the Holiday Inn waved scores of bright red signs that read ``Florio Lied'' as Quayle urged votes for Mangini. ``The Democrats, they'll raise your taxes whenever they get a chance,'' the vice president said. ``Just look what's going on in Trenton. Your governor's taken a page right out of the book written by Michael Dukakis and Mario Cuomo... ``Your high-taxing governor has had the best training in the world for raising taxes, years and years of loyal and devoted service to the Democrat majority in the Congress,'' Quayle said. Long before the budget negotiations, the Republican theme was that Democrats were the party of taxing and spending. Ronald Reagan pushed it, after muscling through the massive federal tax cut of 1981 that was supposed to spur the economy and lead to a balanced budget. It didn't work; the deficit soared despite economic expansion. The government reported Friday that it hit a near-record $220.4 billion during the year ended Sept. 30. The Republicans argue that is because of excessive spending. The Democrats counter that revenues are out of whack, too, and have been since the big Reagan tax reduction, despite tax increases since. Quayle said taxes were part of the budget deal only because the Democrats were adamant and insisted that ``you've got to put taxes on the table.'' So the question shifted from no taxes to which taxes. ``The wealthy are going to be paying more taxes, everyone can be assured of that,'' Quayle said on the political point that worries Republicans most. ``The wealthy are going to be paying their fair share despite what the perception is or is not.'' ``We're the party that is trying to keep the taxes down,'' Bush said last week. ``When they talk about taxing the rich, they're talking about taxing the working men and women of this country.'' ``I believe the American people know who's responsible for increased taxes,'' Quayle said. But he acknowledged that the whole budget flap had been politically painful for the administration, and therefore, for Republicans. ``We've had a couple rough weeks,'' he said. But he added that election campaigns go in cycles. ``I think we'll start to turn it around,'' he said. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 25 years.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Say They Mistranslated Key Word in Report
With AM-Israel, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Government Press Office said Sunday it mistranslated a key word in the report by the commission that investigated the Oct. 8 riot on the Temple Mount in which 20 Palestinians died. A sentence in the English version of the Hebrew-language report said that during the police charge against stone-throwing Arabs, there was ``indiscriminate use of live ammunition.'' The Government Press Office, which translated the report, said Sunday that ``indiscriminate'' should have read ``unsupervised.'' It apologized for the error. The report of the government-appointed commission was published Friday. Yossi Olmert, director of the Government Press Office, said the announcement of the correction was delayed because of the Jewish Sabbath.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Accused Of Reluctance To Try War Crimes Cases
DOC.TEXT: Lawyers and human rights activists say the prosecution of three alleged Nazi collaborators has been stalled or dragged out because of a reluctance to expose French complicity in the Holocaust. War crimes charges against one of the men, Maurice Papon, have been pending for seven years. Another, Rene Bousquet, was implicated in 1949 for his activities as police chief in the Vichy regime, but only now faces the possibility of a trial. The third alleged war criminal, Paul Touvier, is on trial for his activities as a pro-Nazi militia chief in Lyon. Representatives of the International Federation of Human Rights say authorities have failed to relieve the judge of other cases to make the trial move more swiftly. ``We believe it is no accident that these three men have not been tried,'' said Yves Jouffa, president of the French League of Human Rights, at a recent news conference. ``It is because they are part of what the English call the establishment, whether it be in politics, business, industry or high society.... This milieu does not want to see its dirty laundry washed in public.'' Bousquet, 81, headed the national police during the Nazi occupation. State prosecutors last month asked that he be investigated in connection with the deportation of 194 Jewish children during the war. A Paris criminal court court ruled Oct. 19 that Bousquet could only be tried by the High Court of the Liberation, formed in 1944 to prosecute officials of the Vichy regime. The Liberation court has been defunct for decades, and the ruling by the Paris judges indicated Bousquet would escape prosecution. However, at the request of state prosecutors, an appeals court plans to make a final ruling on the jurisdiction issue Nov. 19. Serge Klarsfeld, a lawyer and prominent Nazi hunter, said senior government officials, including President Francois Mitterrand, appear reluctant to pursue the case. ``I think Mitterrand doesn't want this trial to open,'' Klarsfeld said. ``I can only hypothesize that there is a certain indulgence toward Vichy.'' Should the case go to trial, Bousquet would be the highest ranking French official in the Vichy government to be tried for crimes against humanity. Bousquet was condemned in 1949 for his activities under Nazi occupation, but the decision was reversed for ``acts accomplished in favor of the Resistance'' - namely, his decision to free some jailed resistance fighters. Jouffa, who spent part of World War II in a French internment camp, said none of the high-ranking French political figures with direct roles in deporting and arresting 100,000 Jews during the war have been brought to justice. He said the recent trial of the Gestapo chief in Lyon, Klaus Barbie, ``was the trial of Nazi Germany, not collaborationist France. The human rights federation said it had organized an inquiry commission to determine why the cases were taking so long. Their report is being submitted to the United Nations and the Council of Europe. ``We hope that the very fact that we have carried out this mission will be enough to create movement in high places and allow these proceedings to be accelerated,'' Jouffa said. Papon, a former budget minister, has been accused of responsibility for the arrests and deportations of 1,700 Jews while an administrator in Bordeaux during the war. Now 81, he served in many high-profile positions after the war, including a stint as Paris police chief. Touvier, 75, worked with Barbie in Lyon. He went into hiding in 1973, and was arrested in May 1989 at a priory in Nice run by followers of Archbishop Marcel Lefevbre, the fundamentalist Roman Catholic leader.

DOC.HEAD: Two Outsiders Competing to Succeed Dukakis
With AM-All's Fair Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to include Illinois among close races; delete Rhode Island. Note language in 3rd graf
DOC.TEXT: The race for Massachusetts governor hardly has been marked by the gentility one might expect from a contest between a university president and an upper-crust Harvard-educated lawyer. Republican William Weld has pulled few punches in his fight with Democrat John Silber, the president of Boston University, a philosopher and Immanuel Kant scholar. Weld refers to Silber as ``Dr. Know It All.'' And despite the fact that Silber called for a cleaned-up campaign, he was forced to apologize last week for calling Weld a ``back-stabbing son of a bitch.'' That was a reference to Weld's resignation from the Justice Department in 1988 because of concerns with the ethics of then-Attorney General Edwin Meese. Weld accused Silber of harboring ``crazy ideas'' when the Democrat suggested some women have neglected their children by deciding to work outside the home. Silber retaliated by criticizing Weld's mother, who died in 1986. Silber said he did not need to be lectured by a multimillionaire ``whose mother never worked a day in her life.'' Weld's mother taught drama and worked as a volunteer for a non-profit company that helped place handicapped people in jobs, protested a Weld spokesman. For all their bickering, Weld and Silber do agree on one thing: their criticism of how Gov. Michael S. Dukakis has handled the job. Dukakis, whose popularity plummeted when the state hit the economic skids after his unsuccessful 1988 presidential run, decided not to seek re-election. Both Silber and Weld have promised to overhaul state government and cut state spending to accommodate state tax collections that have been in a nose dive. With polls showing Silber slightly ahead, the dogfight is likely to come down to the wire. The uncertainty is reinforced by polls before the primary election that failed to anticipate Silber's win and understated Weld's margin of support. Weld served as a U.S. attorney in Massachusetts, gaining a reputation as an aggressive prosecutor of white-collar crime, before joining the Justice Department, where he was an assistant U.S. attorney general. The political outsider image cultivated by both candidates has served them well in a state where angry primary voters kicked out the incumbent attorney general, denied the House speaker the nomination for treasurer and knocked out several incumbent state legislators. Republicans see the Nov. 6 election as their best chance to capture the governor's office since 1974, but Silber's criticism of Dukakis has made it more difficult for Weld to run against the lame duck. Dukakis has said he'll vote for Silber despite their cool relationship. ``People, even if they don't love him, are beginning to see that this guy stands for something and that the other guy doesn't,'' Dukakis said. But Senate President William Bulger, one of Silber's earliest supporters, said he didn't want ``to presume (Silber) will be elected governor. He's in a very difficult political race.'' The major issue dividing the two men is an initiative that, if passed, would roll back most state taxes and fees to 1988 levels. The state has had several major tax and fee increases in the last two years. Weld supports the initiative. While Silber has endorsed its motives, he has said the initiative itself ``will force the collapse of the state government and our economy by rigid formula.'' Despite tax increases and recent sharp spending cuts, Massachusetts still faces a precariously balanced budget. Both candidates acknowledge spending will have to be cut further with or without the initiative, which would trim $1.2 billion from state tax collections this fiscal year and about double that in fiscal 1992. The Silber-Weld race is one of 14 tight campaigns for governor around the country with just over a week to go until Election Day. The others are in California, Texas, Florida, Alabama, Nebraska, Kansas, Maine, Illinois, Vermont, Alaska, Oregon, Ohio and Oklahoma.

DOC.HEAD: Jacques Demy, French Film Director, Dead at 59
DOC.TEXT: Jacques Demy, the French master of musical comedies best known for his 1963 film ``Les Parapluies de Cherbourg,'' has died of a brain hemorrhage brought on by leukemia, associates said Sunday. He was 59. Demy died Saturday night, the associates said. Demy brought to France the musical comedy style popularized in Hollywood but never big in this country. Among his other major musicals was the acclaimed ``Les Demoiselles de Rochefort'' (The Maidens of Rochefort) of 1966, starring Catherine Deneuve and her elder sister, Francoise Dorleac. He also directed the film version of the fairy tale ``Peau d'Ane'' (Donkey Skin) in 1970 starring Miss Deneuve. ``Les Parapluies de Cherbourg'' (The Umbrellas of Cherbourg) firmly established Demy as a leading director of musicals by winning the Palme D'Or award at the Cannes Film Festival. Born in the Atlantic village of Pontchateau in 1931, Demy studied at the Technical College of Fine Arts in Nantes and the Technical School of Photography in Paris. After turning out several short films, his first feature-length piece, ``Lola'' (1960) with Anouk Aimee, was warmly received by critics who placed him among those active in ``nouveau cinema'' at the turn of the decade. In 1962 he directed ``La Baie des Anges'' (Window of Angels) with Jeanne Moreau, a story of two gamblers at the oceanside casinos of Nice, which also reflected Demy's passion of the sea. That year he married fellow director Agnes Varda. He won the national Grand Prix of Cinema for his 1982 ``Chambre en Ville'' (A Room in the City). He called the film a ``musical tragicomedy,'' explaining at the time that ``in the last 20 years, since `Les Parapluies de Cherbourg,' things have changed. My story is more violent, more passionate, and has become more funny.'' His last film was ``Trois Places Pour le 26'' (Three Places for the 26) in 1988, which marked the return of Yves Montand to cinema. He and Ms. Varda had one son, Mathieu.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS OAKLAND, Calif.-dated last item in rdp to CORRECT spelling of O'Connor in penultimate graf.
DOC.TEXT: David Letterman has come up with several reasons the Oakland Athletics lost the World Series to the Cincinnati Reds. The A's were ``too busy choreographing nude locker room dance number for female reporters,'' according to the No. 1 reason on the talk show host's list of ``Top 10 Oakland A's excuses.'' Among the other reasons were that the A's were too busy worrying about the budget crisis and were upset that Sinead O'Connor refused to sing the national anthem. The Irish singer created a brouhaha this summer when she wouldn't let the anthem be performed before a concert of hers. The No. 10 excuse: ``Thought it was best out of 17 - planned on stunning nine-game comeback,'' Letterman said Friday night.

DOC.HEAD: In Gallop To Adjournment, Congress Hits a Rough Spot or Two
DOC.TEXT: When the congressional session - and the hour - grow late, the strain takes its toll on lawmakers, and each reflects it in different ways. Here are some vignettes from Congress' closing hours last week. --- Rep. Henry Hyde, R-Ill., was upset. One of Congress' most conservative lawmakers, Hyde thought the House had passed a tough anti-crime bill earlier this year. But Saturday night, when the adjournment-bound House debated the compromise version of the bill reached between the House and Senate, he was no longer pleased. ``It left here as Arnold Schwarzenegger,'' he lamented, ``and came back as Woody Allen.'' --- The House Rules Committee met at 10 p.m. Friday to decide the procedure for the debate on the deficit-reduction bill, a measure on which a final vote was not taken until seven the next morning. Rep. Lynn Martin, R-Ill., didn't like the idea of a debate that seemed likely to not even begin until 2 a.m. She suspected that legislative leaders trying to ram the deficit-reduction bill through the House were hoping to bring the bill to the floor when lawmakers were too weary to resist. ``Is that part of the deal, you don't want them alive and awake?'' she asked House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif. ``Some would argue that at 9 a.m., they're not alive and awake,'' Panetta responded. --- Martin also was disconcerted because the Rules Committee was being asked to make a decision about a complicated, crucial bill that none of the panel's members had even seen. That's life on the Rules panel, which is dominated by Democrats. ``Are we going to get to see the bill?'' she asked. ``Not until we do,'' responded Rep. Anthony Bielenson, D-Calif. ``You mean we're not going to see the bill?'' she said. ``It's easier that way,'' he answered. --- Much consternation was caused by the revelation that a provision was slipped into the deficit-reduction bill giving a tax break to an insurance company in Portland, Maine, the home state of Senate Democratic Leader George Mitchell. The 1,600-page measure was so complex that few lawmakers had much information about what it actually contained. The Maine tax break was eventually removed from the bill. But for some reason, it put a sour taste in the mouths of many legislators. ``I'd really hate it to find out after we voted it that the state of Maine was forgiven all taxation until the next generation,'' worried Rep. Louise Slaughter, D-N.Y. --- The ranking Republican on the House Budget Committee, Rep. Bill Frenzel of Minnesota, is one of Capitol Hill's most accomplished budget quote-meisters. Here are his explanations of why a pair of provisions were in the bill: A series of taxes on luxury items such as fancy cars and yachts: ``To satisfy the Democratic blood lust to get at rich people.''
