A seemingly non-budgetary section that dealt with noise at airports: ``To quiet down four committees in the House and to keep the secretary of transportation from going ballistic.'' --- The House's Democratic leaders spent much of Friday lining up votes for the budget. Because they were only counting on about 40 votes from the Republican minority, Democrats figured that they needed 180 of their 258 members to assure House passage. One problem they faced was with the Congressional Black Caucus. Many of the group's 24 members - all Democrats - said they would oppose the deficit-reduction bill as a protest against the Senate's failure earlier in the week to override President Bush's veto of the civil rights bill. Rep. Charles Rangel, D-N.Y., said leaders were trying to coax him into voting for the bill. What could they offer him to get his vote, he was asked. ``It's going to have to be the top of the presidential ticket,'' he joked. Rangel ended up voting against the budget.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Ship Boarded, Searched
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf pvs, `The ship's ...' to CORRECT first reference to U.S. frigate. Pickup 8th pvs, `The Darwin...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: An Iraqi tanker was boarded by U.S. Marines Sunday after two warships fired warning shots across its bow when it refused to stop, U.S. Navy officials said. For the first time during the sea blockade against Iraq, two warplanes from the carrier USS Independence flew six low-level passes near the ship as part of the interception, Navy Cmdr. J.D. Van Sickle said. As of Oct. 26, some 2,738 ships had been intercepted in the Persian Gulf region as part of the blockade. There have been 282 ships boarded, included 224 by U.S. forces. Twelve ships have been diverted to other ports. The ship was allowed to proceed, however, after a search party conducted an inspection and found no goods banned under the U.N. sanctions imposed on Iraq in retaliation for its Aug. 2 conquest of Kuwait. ``No prohibitive cargo was found, and the ship was allowed to proceed. It is now under way,'' said Van Sickle. The vessel Amuriyah was intercepted before dawn in the North Arabian Sea off Marirah Island near the coast of Oman. The ship's master told the Australian guided-missile cruiser HMAS Darwin and the U.S. Navy frigate Reasoner it was headed for Basra, Iraq, but refused to stop and allow a boarding party. The Darwin fired .50-caliber machine gun rounds across the bow at about 7:15 a.m. local time (1:15 a.m. EST) and the Reasoner fired two rounds from its 5-inch deck guns about 10 minutes later. ``It ignored the warning shots and signaled its intention it was not going to stop,'' Van Sickle said. A team of Marines from the USS Ogden flew in by helicopter and slid down ropes onto the ship's deck at 8:50 a.m. (2:50 a.m. EST). A boarding tem of Australians, U.S. Coast Guards members and U.S. Navy personnel conducted the five-hour search. The USS Ogden and British frigate HMS Brazen also assisted in the operation, the officials said. The Amuriyah weighs 157,000 tons when loaded and was built in 1977.

DOC.HEAD: Forecaster Predicts Rage For Organic Coffee, Gourmet Ice And Having Fun
DOC.TEXT: ``Success surgery'' for executives, organic coffee and ``gourmet'' ice - yes, ice, not ice cream - will be all the rage next year, a forecaster predicts, who says America is quickly approaching a time when baby boomers just want to have fun. Other trends to expect in 1991: ``retro-chic'' appliances with a post-World War II look; revived interest in station wagons, libraries; the 1960s look in clothes, and Italian fast-food franchises, according to ``The American Forecaster 1991.'' On the homefront, the Santa Fe home interior look will be out, as will be Japan-bashing. And baseball doubleheaders will go the way of Shoeless Joe. Author Kim Long says desktop lunches and executive facelifts will be symptomatic of Americans' intensified interest in their work, but 1991 will not be the dawn of an age of workaholism. ``I think the '90s is going to be a fun decade,'' said Long. `Most people in the big `baby boom' age group will be in their 40s and 50s. They will have earned a living and raised families. I think that equates to a potential situation where people will look to do fun things, to worry less about what the neighbors think or families think. ``They may drop out of careers to do what they always wanted to do, to be what they always wanted to be when they grew up,'' he said. But corporate America won't turn on and drop out altogether. Companies in 1991 will be streamlining their operations to remain competitive. Long looks for more workers to eat lunch at their desks so they can become more productive. Along the same line, executives will turn more often to cosmetic surgery as a way to prop up their corporate image, Long said. The sought-after look will be ``relatively small noses, not a prominent chin - but a chinless looks is unacceptable, and wrinkles would be out,'' he said. Long, 41, of Denver began writing the Forecaster in 1983, and his book sells about 10,000 copies a year. This year's edition, which will be released in November, has a new look to it. It is pocket-size, and its cover is illustrated by a human head with lightning bolts shooting from it. Long said he researches trends by reading numerous newspapers and magazines, keeping files on particular topics, and monitors computer data bases. In it, Long predicts that organic coffee, grown without pesticides, will hit big in 1991. ``That has all the makings of a major food fad,'' he said. ``People are becoming a lot more literate about what they put into their mouths. They're willing to spend more money for the details.'' Another trend that has hit Japan and soon will arrive in the United States is ``gourmet'' ice - ice up to 10,000 years old that is chipped from Alaskan ice floes and is valued for its purity. Clothing fashions will continue their tilt toward 1960s styles - hot pants, minikirts and baggy jeans for women, and garish ties and baggy pants for men. Long says shoulder pads in women's clothing will become just another old trend as designers focus their attention on emphasizing women's busts. The boxy appliances that marked the dawn of the post-World War II era will make a reappearance in 1991, Long said. ``It's the visual appeal, so solid and heavy - the beginning of the atomic era. It looks appropriate to certain people now,'' he said. People also are rediscovering libraries, and the number of libraries is on the rise, said Long. ``The new buzzword is `information literacy,' teaching people about how to be more capable of finding their own answers.'' Besides writing the Forecaster, Long is a newspaper columnist and is author of a soon-to-be-published directory called ``Educational Destinations and Field Trips.''

DOC.HEAD: Youth Staging Halloween Hangman Gag Accidentally Hangs Himself
DOC.TEXT: A 15-year-old who was staging a haunted house hangman gag accidentally hanged himself at a private Halloween party, authorities said. The death of William Anthony Odom, a ninth-grader from Charlotte, N.C., was similar to that of a 17-year-old who staged a Halloween hangman stunt in Lakewood, N.J., a week ago. Odom was pronounced dead Friday night by York County Coroner Jim Chapman in the basement of the home of his aunt, Diane Boyd, which Odom and several of his friends had decorated as a haunted house. Odom was inside a free-standing wooden cupboard, intending to fake a hangman scene, said his grandmother Hattie Carpenter, who was at the party. He was dressed as a pirate, and around his neck was a 3-foot length of nylon rope tied into a hangman's knot hanging from a bar. ``It was a slip-knot-type noose; the more pressure you apply, the tighter it gets,'' Chapman said. ``Evidently, it was tight enough to cause some problems with his breathing, and he either passed out or panicked.'' Chapman said Odom was tall enough to stand up in the cabinet, but a group of children found him ``sitting down in the closet with the noose around his neck and his neck to the side.'' Chapman said he's unsure how the rope tightened. Possibly, he said, Odom slipped and lost his balance or was playing with the knot. He said it's possible that the knot gradually tightened and reduced the amount of blood to Odom's brain, causing him to faint and then suffocate. X-rays Saturday showed no serious injury to the neck, indicating that the neck wasn't snapped by a sudden action, such as tripping. Odom's grandfather, Harvey Carpenter, said he and Ms. Boyd tried to revive him, but the boy was dead by the time an emergency medical team arrived. On Oct. 20, a 17-year-old New Jersey youth accidentally hanged himself at a Halloween haunted hayride. Brian Jewell had pretended to hang from a gallows but his body was found hanging from the gallows with his feet on the ground.

DOC.HEAD: Is That You, Daffy?
DOC.TEXT: Donald and Daffy weren't there. But there were plenty of quacks, made by everyone from the pros to the hacks. Dressed in hunting jackets and caps, 20 competitors from five states gathered Saturday in the parking lot of a Portage plumbing company for the Indiana Duck Calling Championship. Topping everyone taking a quack at the state title was Kyle Fleming, 33, a steel mill supervisor from Valparaiso. He came in first with the five judges with his 90-second routine of duck calls, and will advance to the world championships in Stuttgart, Ark. Duck calling judges rely on keen ears, because they aren't allowed to see the callers perform. That keeps the judges from favoring contestants they know or have competed against. ``We're imagining that we're in a duck blind with the caller as he simulates certain duck calls,'' said Jerry Trueblood, a judge from Detroit. ``We're looking for a smooth flow and an even sequence of calls.'' Trueblood, a defending regional champion, said the callers are required to perform a call to feed, a highball (or call to a distant duck), a greeting and a call back. ``Once you learn competitive duck calling, you can really call ducks down and improve your chances for shooting them,'' said Ray Wright, a former Indiana duck calling champion. ``Any damn fool can plug a duck from 20 yards away with a shotgun, but it takes a good hunter to call him down from the skies.''

DOC.HEAD: New Child Care Program Includes Tax Credits, Grants to States
With AM-Congress-Look Back Bjt
DOC.TEXT: New grant programs for child care and higher tax credits for low-income families with children are part of the mammoth budget agreement Congress approved before it left town for the year early Sunday. The move marked the first time since World War II that the federal government has supported child care for working parents outside of welfare and employment programs, said Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., one of its authors. Sponsors said the 750,000 children will receive aid in the initial year of the program, which also will require states to establish health, safety, registration and quality requirements. While President Bush had supported the concept of child-care assistance during his 1988 campaign, he opposed elements of the House and Senate packages until two weeks ago, when White House officials reached agreement with Dodd on the block grant program. Under the bill, church-run day care centers will be eligible for the federal subsidies, a recognition that churches play an important role in child care in many areas, overriding concerns about separation of church and state. The package also includes a grant program providing money to the states. They, in turn, are to pass on a portion directly to low-income families to cover part of child-care expenses, or to the child-care centers as subsidies for individual children. The program will receive $2.5 billion for the first three years, with the total expected to reach $5 billion by the fifth year. A separate, smaller grant program also will provide money to the states to be passed along to poor families for child-care assistance. Unlike the other program, it will become a new entitlement program under Title 4 of the Social Security Act. As an entitlement it will automatically be included in the federal budget annually and will not have to compete for yearly appropriations. The package anticipates a cost of $700 million over five years for this program. In addition, the Earned Income Tax Credit now available to low-income working families with children would be expanded. The bill adjusts the credit based on family size and provides a supplemental $500 credit for eligible families with children under the age of 1. The bill estimates the credit expansion will cost $12.4 billion over five years. The credit is refundable, meaning that taxpayers whose credits exceed their income tax liability are paid the difference by the government. It is not directly tied to child-care expenses. Families with a stay-at-home parent providing care for their own children would receive the credit as well. The maximum credit in 1990 is 14 percent of the first $6,810 of earned income, or $953. It is reduced as the adjusted gross income reaches $10,743, and is totally eliminated at an income level of $20,270. The bill increases the credit gradually so that by 1994, the credit would be 23 percent for a one-child family and 25 percent for the two-child family. Income eligibility levels rise with inflation. Three-quarters of the $2.5 billion child-care block grant program must be used by the states to provide direct child care services, including improvements in quality and availability. The remaining portion would be devoted to early childhood development or before-and after-school child care services.

DOC.HEAD: More Than 20,000 Welcome Mandela in Western Japan
LaserPhoto OSA1
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela told more than 20,000 Japanese at a rally Sunday that he would seek financial help from their government for his anti-apartheid movement. The black leader, who is to meet Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu on Monday, addressed the crowd at a complex in the western city of Osaka on the second day of his visit to Japan. Later Sunday, he spoke before 2,000 people at a fund-raiser in Tokyo. Mandela, 72, deputy president of the African National Congress, said he will ask leaders what kind of support the congress can expect from Japan in efforts to abolish Pretoria's apartheid policy. ``We are here not only because you are a very rich country with a great deal of skill in economic affairs. We are here because we regard you as our friends and as our allies,'' he said. ``We do expect the Japanese government and Japanese businesses to get involved in helping develop our economy after apartheid has been scrapped,'' he said. He also said he would ask the government and Japanese business enterprises in Japan to provide funds both for anti-apartheid activities and to help build a new South Africa. Mandela arrived in Japan Saturday after visiting India, Indonesia and Australia. He is to visit Malaysia and Brunei before returning home, Kanbayashi said. Japan has banned direct private investment in South Africa since the 1960s and does not station an ambassador in Pretoria, although it maintains diplomatic relations with South Africa. Japan also bans imports of South African iron and steel and limits cultural, sports and tourism exchanges. Mandela was freed in February after more than 27 years in South African prisons.

DOC.HEAD: Paper to Continue Publishing `Satanic Verses'
DOC.TEXT: A Nepali weekly will continue serializing Salman Rushdie's ``The Satanic Verses'' despite a request by the government to stop, the editor said Sunday. Communications Minister Yog Prasad Upadhyaya contacted the weekly in response to complaints by representatives of the Moslem community that the novel hurt their religious feelings. Shiv Kumar Khadga, editor of the weekly Janjyoti, said the 48th chapter in the serial would run as scheduled Monday. ``There is no legal obligation for us to stop the publication and we have no intention of hurting anyone. We are printing the serial to give the Nepalese readers a taste of a fine literary piece,'' he said in an interview. Only 3 percent of Nepal's 17 million people are Moslems, and about 90 percent are Hindus. The rest are Buddhists and Christians. Rushdie has been in hiding in Britain since February 1989, when Iran's Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini declared the novel blasphemous and decreed that the British author should be killed.

DOC.HEAD: Police Shooting of Unarmed Stockbroker Follows Complaints Against Force
DOC.TEXT: Police checking a report of a prowler entered an apartment at 3:30 a.m. and shot a 24-year-old stockbroker to death when he got out of bed in his nightclothes to see what was wrong. The officer who shot the man was placed on paid leave pending an investigation, police said. The police department, already struggling with allegations of police brutality and racism, said it was an accidental shooting of an innocent person. It is believed to be the sixth shooting death committed by Kansas City police officers this year. In one, four officers fired 19 times at a man brandishing a barbecue fork. In another, an officer killed a man who was spraying him with a fire extinguisher. None of the officers involved in those two killings was indicted. Terry D. Barnes, 24, was shot once between the eyes Saturday in his apartment. ``I just hope that this case will draw the line on where the police can kill an innocent man. Where do you draw the line?'' said Andy Brez, 23, Barnes' roommate. He was sleeping in another bedroom when police entered the apartment. ``I woke up to the word `Police!''' he said. ``I was scared to death.'' Brez said he stayed in his bedroom until an officer opened his door and told him to stay inside. He said Barnes was engaged to be married next June. Police spokesman Sgt. Greg Mills said Barnes made ``a kind of lunging motion'' when the officer opened his bedroom door. ``This is a tragic chain of events that is regrettable for Mr. Barnes' family and for this officer,'' Police Chief Steven Bishop said. ``The officers were reacting appropriately to a number of circumstances which together led them to that apartment.'' Residents of an apartment complex adjacent to Barnes' building had called police to report that someone kicked in their front door. When officers arrived, other residents of the complex said they saw a man run toward Barnes' building. Some residents thought they heard the prowler run to the third floor, where Barnes lived. Two officers, whose names were not disclosed, noticed the door to Barnes' apartment was not tightly shut and entered the apartment. One officer opened a bedroom door and encountered Barnes, unarmed, dressed in a T-shirt and boxer shorts, standing near a bed 5 to 8 feet from the doorway, Mills said. Barnes ran at the officer and the officer fired, Mills said. Mills told The Kansas City Star the officers ``acted responsibly by going into the apartment'' because they had good reason to believe the suspect might be in there. But the department stopped short of defending the action taken by the officer who fired the shot. ``We are defending the officers being in that apartment,'' Mills said. ``As for the shooting itself, we will make no assessment of the propriety of that until after the investigation. ``I think it's accurate to say (the officer) did feel threatened.'' The officer, a two-year veteran of the force, was placed on paid administrative leave pending an internal investigation and an investigation by a Clay County grand jury. Some of the previous police shootings have prompted calls for the department to re-evaluate officers' conduct and training. In previous interviews, Chief Bishop said only a few of his 1,200 officers violate citizens' rights. ``We're part of the problem out there on the street, and we've got to get back to good, basic police work,'' said Bishop, a 20-year veteran of the force who became chief in June. Police officials have said they are developing a ``behavior modification'' program for offending officers.

DOC.HEAD: Research Animals Freed From Cages at University
DOC.TEXT: BUFFALO, N.Y. (AP) Hundreds of mice, rats and hamsters used for research were released from their cages at the state University of New York at Buffalo Medical School, but no animal rights group claimed responsibility. The animals were found scampering around five rooms Saturday morning by a technician arriving for work, said school spokeswoman Linda Grace-Kobas. ``They opened the cages, and the mice and the rats (and hamsters) got out of the cages, but they did not escape from the rooms,'' she said. There were no signs of a break-in or indication why the animals were released. ``Usually animal rights people leave a message,'' she said. ``There were no notes. No `Save the Animals.' This was strange. It seemed random. It seemed pointless.'' University officials were trying to determine what effect the animals' release will have on research projects in which they were used, she said. ``By letting them out, it disrupts the experiments,'' she said, adding that some of the experiments are based on the animals being in a closed enviroment. Also, since not all the animals were tagged, researchers may not be able to determine which animals belonged to what experiments.

DOC.HEAD: Security Forces Seal Moslem Shrine, Arrest Thousands
LaserPhoto AYO2
DOC.TEXT: Police arrested thousands more Hindu pilgrims Sunday, including a member of a Hindu royal family, in an attempt to avoid more bloodshed in a dispute over a Moslem shrine in this town. The Hindu-Moslem conflict over the shrine claimed at least 96 lives in rioting last week and has jeopardized Prime Minister V.P. Singh's government. More than 60,000 people were arrested by Saturday as troops sealed off Ayodhya and the borders of Uttar Pradesh state from a swarm of Hindu pilgrims. Police gave no figure for the number of arrests Sunday, but Press Trust of India and United News of India said 15,000 were detained at one southern border crossing. Among them was Vijaya Raje Scindia, vice president of the right-wing Hindu party Bharatiya Janata. She was the maharani, or princess, of Gwalior before India abolished princely states 20 years ago. Mrs. Scindia was arrested on charges of ``violating a prohibitory order,'' United News reported. The state government had banned the leaders of several Hindu fundamentalist groups from the state. The news agencies said 300 truckloads of Hindu pilgrims accompanying Mrs. Scindia were driven to temporary jails in schools and public areas around the state. Twelve members of Parliament also were detained by police forming a security net around the shrine. ``It's like a war zone. Not even an ant can get past us,'' said one police officer protecting the shrine. The controversy is centered on a 16th century mosque, the Babri Masjid, in this town of 40,000 people about 300 miles southeast of New Delhi. Hindu fundamentalists say the mosque stands on the birthplace of the god Rama. They say they will replace the structure with a temple and have set Wednesday for beginning construction. The government, saying it is obliged to defend minority interests, has pledged not to allow the mosque to be displaced until the courts decide the issue. The Bharatiya Janata Party withdrew support from Singh's National Front coalition Tuesday. Singh's minority government depended on the Hindu party and the Communist-led Left Front for its survival. A United News report quoted Singh as saying Sunday that the Hindu party was trying to ``usurp power, even at the cost of communal conflagration and the country's unity.'' Singh must face a vote of confidence in Parliament on Nov. 7. The Bharatiya Janata and the opposition Congress party have said they will vote against Singh, which virtually assures his defeat. Elections are likely early next year. ``The (political) matter is closed. It is with the security forces now, and they will do their duty,'' said the police official at a barricade on the road to Aydohya. Heavily armed policemen manned the barrier. All entry points to Ayodhya in a 60-mile radius are blocked by barricades, he said. The national railway suspended service through the state. About 200,000 policemen and paramilitary forces have fanned across the state. In Ayodya, an indefinite curfew imposed Friday was lifted for just two hours Sunday afternoon. Officials refuse to say how many policemen are deployed around the shrine, but some officers said the figure was about 20,000. Policemen lounged in the shade of narrow lanes leading to the shrine, playing with monkeys who inhabit the area. Moslems comprise 30 percent of the 120 million people in Uttar Pradesh. Though Moslems are only 12 percent of India's 880 million people, they live in almost every Indian state. Hindus are 82 percent of the population. Religious tensions between Hindus and Moslems erupt periodically, and dozens of people are killed in clashes every year.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Fires Oil Minister; Cancels Rationing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with agency not giving amount of reserves, doubts about official statement, details. Pickup 4th pvs, `The Iraqi ...' Minor editing thereafter to CONFORM.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Iraq fired its oil minister Sunday and canceled a fuel rationing program, saying it was imposed by mistake, an official report said. The minister was replaced by Saddam Hussein's son-in-law. It was not immediately clear why the rationing, which began Tuesday, was stopped. The report by the official Iraqi News Agency said the Oil Ministry had miscalculated the amount of chemical additives necessary to refine crude oil into gasoline and other products such as lubricants. ``It was evident that they (chemicals) were enough for double the period estimated by the Oil Ministry,'' the agency said. It said the ministry of industry ``was capable of manufacturing the needed solutions.'' The report did not specify the amount of the needed chemicals Iraq had. A well-placed oil industry source said there indeed was an imminent shortage of the chemicals, which had been imported before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. U.N. trade sanctions apparently have severely curtailed imports of the chemicals, but Iraq may have taken whatever supplies were in Kuwait when it invaded. The source said Saddam may have fired the official, Issam Chalabi, to blame him for the imminent shortage of chemicals. The Iraqi agency said ``a republican decree'' relieved Chalabi of his post. It said another decree appointed Hussein Kamel, minister of industry and military industrialization, as acting oil minister. Chalabi has been oil minister since 1986. Before that he had a long career as an oil administrator, including a stint as head of Iraq's national oil company. Kamel is a son-in-law of Saddam. In addition to his ministerial duties, he reportedly runs one of the five secret police organizations through which Saddam keeps a tight rein on Iraq. The well-informed oil industry source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that for more than a year there have been signs that Kamel has been attempting to expand his authority into oil production. The source said that despite the cancellation of rationing, recent travelers from Iraq have said that the shortage is ``really biting'' and that Iraqis are asking why they have such shortages when there is still plenty of crude oil for local consumption despite the international embargo on Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Bush To Sign Bill With El Salvador Aids Cuts, Egypt Debt Forgiveness
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Sunday he will sign a $15.5 billion foreign aid spending bill despite his concerns about its 50 percent cut in military aid to El Salvador. Bush at first was unresponsive when asked about the bill's fate as he played a midday round of golf here. But as he left the links later he said he had spoken to his national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, about the matter, and told reporters he would sign the bill. Asked about the provision that would halve El Salvador's $85 million in military aid, Bush said ``Yes, we're very much concerned about it.'' But the bill, approved late Saturday in the waning hours of the 101st Congress, also has something Bush badly wants - forgiveness of $6.7 billion in past military debt Egypt owes the United States. The administration sought the debt relief as a gesture of thanks to Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, who has taken a leading role in marshaling Arab opposition to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. The rest of the bill provides economic, military and development aid for U.S. friends and allies around the globe, including $3 billion for Israel and $2.1 billion for Egypt, the two primary aid recipients. The El Salvador provision was pushed through by congressional Democrats, whose outrage was heightened by the killing nearly a year ago of six Jesuit priests, their housekeeper and her daughter in San Salvador. Eight military officials since have been charged in the crime, but none has come to trial. The cut represents a sharp departure from 10 years of U.S. policy which has maintained that military aid was important to bolster the San Salvador government in the face of attacks from leftist guerillas. Administration lobbyists fought hard against the provision on Capitol Hill. Under the bill, the military aid would be cut to $42.5 million in the year that began Oct. 1. Supporters say the cut will put pressure on both sides - the government and the leftist FMLN rebels - to bring their decade-long war to a negotiated, diplomatic end. If the rebels of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front mount a major offensive that threatens the government, or walk away from United Nations-sponsored peace talks, the aid cut could be restored, bringing military support back to its old level of $85 million. But if the government should fail to bargain in good faith with the rebels toward reforms and a cease-fire, it could lose the rest of its military aid. The provisions would leave intact the nearly $300 million in economic, food and development aid that flows to El Salvador.

DOC.HEAD: Cold Air Flows Into Ohio Valley, Northeast
DOC.TEXT: Frigid air flowed southward into the Ohio Valley on Sunday, while southerly wind boosted temperatures on the Plains into the 60s and 70s. Clouds and blustery northwesterly wind held Sunday afternoon temperatures in the 30s and 40s in the upper Great Lakes region. That wind also pushed cold air into the Northeast, and parts of the Ohio Valley expected the first frost or freeze of the season by Monday morning. A freeze warning was posted for all of Ohio except the northeast corner. Freeze advisories were issued for northeastern Kentucky and southern Indiana. But to the west, strong southerly wind helped afternoon temperatures warm into the 60s and 70s in the northern and central Plains. Low pressure tracking across southern Canada with the wind produced scattered showers across the Northeast, and snow was expected in parts of New England. In the Northwest, a cold front produced a few showers Sunday in northern Idaho and western Montana. Showers associated with an upper level weather disturbance moved along the coast of Washington state and Oregon. Temperatures early Sunday dipped into the 20s in New England, and over parts of Nebraska, the Dakotas, Iowa, Minnesota and Wisconsin. Sunday's low for the Lower 48 states was 15 at Warroad, Minn.

DOC.HEAD: Hungary Backs Away From 70 Percent Gasoline Price Increase
DOC.TEXT: The government backed away from a 70 percent gasoline price increase Sunday after two days of crippling nationwide road and bridge blockades by protesting taxi and truck drivers. Industry and Trade Minister Peter Akos Bod told drivers the government was prepared to accept a 50 percent increase pending passage of a law that allows the market to set the price of gasoline. Bod said that if the legislation was not adopted, the original, higher price increase would again take effect. The center-right government coalition has a parliamentary majority, and passage of the law was a near certainty. Unions representing the truck and taxi drivers and their employers accepted the main points of the government offer. Taxi and truck drivers on Friday and Saturday used their vehicles to block streets and bridges nationwide, crippling Hungary for two days. The blockade was eased Sunday as negotiations with the government progressed. While negotiators met in the Labor Ministry on Sunday, an angry pro-government crowd of about 10,000, led by members of Prime Minister Jozsef Antall's Hungarian Democratic Forum, gathered outside. Some demonstrators carried placards reading: ``Fascism, Marxism, Taxiism,'' and ``No to Proletarian Dictatorship.'' One huge placard alluded to the street terror of 1956 - when Soviet tanks crushed an anti-Communist revolution - saying, ``In 1956 tanks, in 1990 taxis.'' The crowd chanted, ``Long live the government!'' and ``Communist Cabbies!'' Defense Minister Lajos Fuer warned the government's patience was growing short. ``Democracy cannot accept illegal acts,'' Fuer told the crowd. ``The government is willing to negotiate, but we won't tolerate anarchy.'' The crowd chanted: ``Punish the offenders!'' Budapest's mayor-elect, Gabor Demszky, went on state television Sunday to appeal for calm. The government rollback followed two days of tense negotiations with protesters. On Saturday, state media briefly reported that the government had proposed across-the-board cuts, but these reports were subsequently described as false by government officials. The talks had foundered for most of Sunday on government reluctance to agree to an overall price reduction. Buses and street cars moved relatively freely in Budapest and other cities for the first time since Friday, when the higher prices went into effect. The government increased gasoline to about $3.80 a gallon from $2.30 a gallon. That is far higher than the American price, even though the average Hungarian earns about $150 a month at current exchange rates. The government said the price increases were needed because of reductions in Soviet shipments and higher oil prices following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The protests represented the most serious sign of discontent with the worsening economic situation as Hungary tries to move toward a free-market system. Elections last spring ended four decades of one-party Communist rule. Hungary's more than $20 billion foreign debt is the highest per capita in the former Soviet bloc. Unemployment and a housing crisis are growing, and inflation is high. The mood of the people in Budapest and elsewhere appeared to back the protesters. Shoppers lining up for bread and milk in anticipation of shortages joked with some of the protesting truckers brewing coffee over field stoves. The blockages were virtually cleared Sunday. In the capital, Danube bridges were cleared of parked vehicles, as were most main thoroughfares. Highways leading to the city also were generally free for traffic. State television reported similar conditions in regional centers jammed with parked trucks and taxis for the previous two days. Most border crossing points were relatively accessible for the first time in two days. The only exception was Gyoer, near main border crossing points with Austria and Czechoslovakia. Abandoned tractor trailers on the main road leading through town continued to block access to the borders.

DOC.HEAD: Bishops Concede Finding Priesthood Candidates is Difficult
DOC.TEXT: Bishops who opposed changing the requirement that priests be celibate ended a meeting Sunday admitting it will not be easy to attract candidates with the needed ``heroism'' for the priesthood. Pope John Paul II had summoned the bishops from around the world for a month-long synod on how to bring in good, committed priests to a church that has suffered defections from the priesthood and seen a drop in seminary enrollments in affluent parts of the world. ``It is clear that many young people find it hard to commit themselves to life-long priesthood, to give up the possibility of marriage and setting up a family, and to choose a life in the spirit of ... poverty, chastity and obedience,'' the bishops said in a statement read during a final Mass led Sunday by the pope in St. Peter's Basilica. ``This is a high ideal. Yet in every age, including our own, we have seen marvelous examples of this heroism, with some even suffering martyrdom for their vocation,'' the bishops said. Throughout his 12-year-old papacy, John Paul consistently has defended the celibacy requirement, which the church sees as a means to give priests more time to devote to their mission and less opportunity for distractions. The requirement has been blamed as one of the reasons for the decline in the number of priests around the world. The pope, buoyed by the bishops' affirmation of celibacy, sought to dispel any speculation that ordination of married men might be permitted in the future. ``This isn't a solution to be taken under consideration,'' John Paul told them in his final speech. ``Without any possibility of doubt, the synod has confirmed the choice of ... celibacy which is proper to the Latin rite.'' The Vatican has excluded from the celibacy requirement priests who converted to Roman Catholism after having married. In addition, several Eastern rite churches which accept the pope's authority are allowed to ordain married men. At the start of the synod on Sept. 30, Vatican officials indicated that the gathering was not seen as an occasion to debate celibacy. Nevertheless, bishops raised the question. While the synod was going on, it was disclosed that the Vatican had questioned a meeting that a U.S. bishop, Donald Wuerl of Pittsburgh, held in June with a group of married ex-priests in California. The bishop denied reports that the Vatican's letter was meant as a rebuke and said ``discussion'' about celibacy would continue. Among the synod's suggestions were the use of better trained seminary teachers and the hiring of lay people, including women, to instruct seminarians. Women are already teaching in some seminaries, but observers said the synod recommendation could make their use more widespread.

DOC.HEAD: NYC Police Play Down Fears of Serial Killer in Bronx Deaths
DOC.TEXT: When a 10-year-old Bronx girl was found asphyxiated, her body dumped near a highway, the slaying raised new fears that a serial killer was on the loose. But even though one man has a link of some kind to her and five other people killed in similar circumstances since 1986, police say that he is not a suspect. In fact, they say, there is no serial killer at work. ``There's only one word to describe this case: bizarre,'' said Inspector Donald E. Moss, who supervises 20 investigators trying to determine whether the links between the deaths are coincidence or follow a pattern. In the latest case, Jessica Guzman was found dead Oct. 17, a week after she disappeared a few blocks from her home. The child's body was found about five miles away, in a wooded area near the Bronx River Parkway. Her death prompted a review of dozens of unsolved killings of young Hispanics in the Bronx borough over the past five years. Among them are the slayings of two teen-agers who were found in 1989, also asphyxiated, also dumped along a Bronx parkway; and three young Hispanic women whose bodies were found in wooded areas near Bronx highways over the last four years. Each of the victims had a link to a 29-year-old Bronx livery cab driver. He faces trial on unrelated charges of scalding and assaulting a girlfriend's 3-year-old son, but police say he is not a suspect in the six killings. Jessica was seen playing in the man's car hours before she vanished. Another of the victims, killed last year along with a 15-year-old boy, was the driver's niece. One victim was said to have dated the driver once; another dated a relative of his, the Daily News reported. The sixth was a friend of one of the other victims. The cab driver denies any involvement. Police said he has a strong alibi for the night Jessica disappeared and is not a suspect in any of the cases. For that reason, they have asked that his name not be published. ``He's the obvious link, but it may be nothing but a coincidence,'' said Moss. ``It's not uncommon for people in the Bronx to know more than one homicide victim, unfortunately.'' Police reject assertions that one person is responsible for the slayings. ``There is no serial killer and there is no linkage between these cases,'' said Deputy Chief Michael Philbin, head of Bronx detectives. ``We don't have a suspect at this time. ``There are significant differences among the cases. Normally, when you're dealing with a serial killer, it's ritualistic.'' Some of the bodies were badly decomposed, making it difficult to pinpoint a cause of death, which in turn makes the cases hard to link, police said. Before Jessica's funeral last Monday, two days after she would have turned 11, 150 people staged a 15-block ``barefoot march'' protesting the killings. More than 2,000 attended her funeral. ``It's like living the same thing all over again. There are too many coincidences,'' said Ana Rosa. She is the grandmother of Heriberto Marrero, 15, the only male among the six victims. His body was found with that of 13-year-old Nilda Cartagena - the driver's niece - in June 1989. Both were asphyxiated. Annette Rosario disappeared in June 1986, on the way home from her 17th birthday party. She was last seen telephoning for a livery cab. An autopsy found her skull had been shattered. Lisa Rodriguez, 21, one of Ms. Rosario's best friends, had one date with the cab driver before she disappeared last June 14, the Daily News reported. Her body was so decomposed the cause of death could not be determined. Shamira Bello, 14, was found strangled in July 1988, her half-naked body dumped in a park not far from where Annette was found. The Daily News said Ms. Bello had been dating a nephew of the driver.

DOC.HEAD: Police Arrest Two More Suspects in Assassination
DOC.TEXT: Two more suspects in the assassination of Egypt's parliament speaker were arrested Sunday as police continued to investigate the role of Moslem extremists in the slaying, security sources said. At least 10 people have been arrested in connection with the Oct. 12 attack that killed People's Assembly speaker Rifaat el-Mahgoub, his driver and four security men, police said. The suspects belong to two militant Moslem groups with a history of violence, including the 1981 assassination of President Anwar Sadat, police allege. But security sources say police are still searching for a wider network of extremists connected to the case. The first suspect arrested confessed last Wednesday to participating in the assassination of el-Mahgoub, who was second in line to the presidency, police said. Early Saturday, authorities raided a Cairo apartment and arrested five men accused of taking part in the slaying. Later, two suspects were killed and two were captured following a shootout at Cairo University, police reported. Security sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, say the men are members of the extremist groups Jihad and Salvation from Hell. Jihad was responsible for Sadat's assassination, and Salvation from Hell was blamed for the attempted killing in 1987 of two former interior ministers and a journalist close to President Hosni Mubarak. Both groups have been charged with attempting to replace Egypt's secular government with an Islamic theocratic rule. Government sources also suspect Iraq had a role in the el-Mahgoub assassination, as punishment for Egypt's stand against Baghdad in the Persian Gulf crisis.

DOC.HEAD: Bhutto Says Followers May Launch Street Protests
LaserPhoto ISL1
DOC.TEXT: Former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto said Sunday her populist party may launch nationwide demonstrations to protest what she called ``massive election fraud'' by her opponents. A right-wing coalition opposing her easily won Wednesday's national elections and Saturday's provincial legislative balloting, dashing Ms. Bhutto's hopes for a comeback following her ouster two months ago. ``At the moment the people are angry,'' Ms. Bhutto said in an interview. ``This is all very distressing. What do you tell people?'' In elections Wednesday for the National Assembly, the policy-making lower house of Parliament that chooses the prime minster, the Islamic alliance defeated Ms. Bhutto by a 2-to-1 margin. Saturday's elections were the bloodiest in Pakistan's 43-year history. At least 33 people were killed and up to 50 others injured in violent clashes. Voting ended after only three hours in at least one constituency in southern Sindh, Ms. Bhutto's power base. Gunmen sprayed a rural voting booth, killing three people and injuring several more, said Election Commissioner Naeemuddin, who uses only one name. The results of at least nine other constituencies were delayed because violence had stalled either voting or counting, Naeemuddin said. Unidentified gunmen ambushed a car taking the son of caretaker Prime Minister Ghulam Mustafa Jatoi to vote, but he escaped by running into the polling station, election officials said. Ms. Bhutto has refused to accept results of either Wednesday's or Saturday's voting, alleging ``sophisticated and systematic'' vote-rigging by the Islamic Democratic Alliance, known by its Urdu-language initials IJI. The alliance denied the allegations, and the charges were not supported by international election observers. ``It has become a habit with the People's Party to allege rigging when they lose,'' said Hussain Haqqani, an alliance spokesman. Ms. Bhutto called on candidates from her party in both contests fo come to Islamabad on Saturday to map out a strategy. ``We will decide then whether to launch a movement against the massive rigging or to play it cool and accept the opposition role in the National Assembly,'' Khurshid Kasuri, secretary-general of Ms. Bhutto's party, told a news conference Sunday. The elections were scheduled after Pakistan's president dismissed Ms. Bhutto on Aug. 6, accusing her 20-month-old government of corruption and incompetence. The former prime minister said she offered to resign the leadership of her party because Pakistan's ``establishment'' is determined to force her out. ``I'm willing to step aside. Why should people suffer all for being in the PPP'' she asked. With 463 of Saturday's 483 races decided, Ms. Bhutto's party was virtually wiped out in eastern Punjab, the largest and wealthiest province and the alliance's stronghold. It was effectively sidelined in the Northwest Frontier Province, where it had ruled before her government was dismissed. Ms. Bhutto and her party also appeared in danger of losing their overwhelming majority in her home province of Sindh. But it was unlikely that Sindh would be decided before next week.

DOC.HEAD: Reagan Calls 1986 Summit a Turning Point in Arms Control Reduction
DOC.TEXT: Former President Reagan's new memoir calls the failed 1986 arms control summit in Iceland one of the ``most disappointing - and ultimately angriest'' days of his presidency, but says it still was a turning point in nuclear arms reduction. In ``Ronald Reagan: An American Life,'' the former president writes that the summit at Reykjavik, Iceland - where he rejected the Soviets' demand to link arms control with reduced U.S. research on the Strategic Defense Initiative - was major step in eventually convincing the Soviets to move forward on arms control. Reagan's memoir, coauthored by journalist Robert Lindsey, is being published by Simon and Schuster. Time magazine is publishing the first of two excerpts in its Nov. 5 issue. Reagan said the bullet wound he suffered in the March 30, 1981, assassination attempt by John Hinckley Jr. was ``the most excruciating pain I had ever felt.'' At first, he wrote, he thought his injury was a broken rib caused when Secret Service agent Jerry Parr shoved him into the presidential limousine and jumped on top of him. The former president said he didn't wear a bulletproof vest that day, as he sometimes did. Noting that the bullet stopped less than an inch from his heart, he said, ``Someone was looking out for me.'' Reagan also told of his days as a radio sports announcer and said that when he was first elected governor of California in 1966, his then 14-year-old daughter Patti cried because ``she didn't like having a member of the Establishment in the family.'' At the Reykjavik summit, Reagan wrote, ``My hopes for a nuclear-free world soared briefly, then fell during one the longest, most disappointing - and ultimately angriest - days of my presidency.'' Reagan and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev had made progress on nuclear arms reduction that ``even now seems breathtaking,'' Reagan said, when Gorbachev ``threw us a curve'' by insisting that it must be linked to reductions in SDI. The summit collapsed. ``Despite a perception by some that the Reykjavik summit was a failure, I think history will show it was a major turning point in the quest for a safe and secure world,'' Reagan wrote. ``I think Gorbachev was ready to talk the next time we met because we had walked out on him at Reykjavik and gone ahead with the SDI.'' Reagan speculated on why Gorbachev decided to allow the major changes that have swept the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe: ``Gorbachev must have realized (his country) could no longer support or control Stalin's totalitarian colonial empire; the survival of the Soviet Union was more important to him. ... ``I might have helped him see that the Soviet Union had less to fear from the West than he thought, and that the Soviet empire in Eastern Europe wasn't needed for the security of the Soviet Union,'' the former president wrote.

There's only one thing for students at Transylvania University to do when Halloween is near - sleep in the tomb of the teacher known for putting a hex on the school. Four Transylvania students won the opportunity to spend a night in the tomb of Constantine Rafinesque, who taught biology at Transylvania from 1819 to 1826 before being fired. ``I can't believe we're sleeping over dead men,'' freshman Shallie Miller of Muncie, Ind., said Friday night while sprawling on a concrete slab that seals Rafinesque's crypt in the school's administration building. And so ended another Rafinesque Week, a time of ghoulish activities started around Halloween in the 1930s to celebrate the unusual botanist's life. Rafinesque, who was born in 1783 in Constantinople, published taxonomic descriptions of 6,700 new plants. But students know him better by his curse. Legend says the university's then-President Horace Holley fired Rafinesque when he discovered the botanist had had an affair with his wife. Outraged, Rafinesque cursed Holley and the school and fled to Philadelphia. Transylvania's administration building mysteriously burned down and Holley died soon after. In 1969, the administration building again caught fire, and every room was gutted except for the one in which Rafinesque is entombed. --- CINCINNATI (AP) - The bride was dreadful, the groom gruesome, but love conquered all in a wedding that looked like something out of ``Fright Night.'' Anthony Taylor and Debra Hutcherson, dressed as Frankenstein and the Bride of Frankenstein, culminated their six-year courtship Saturday in the back yard of their home with a Halloween-style wedding. ``You always see pretty brides and pretty weddings,'' said Hutcherson, 32. ``I just wanted my day to be different.'' Different it was - even friends and relatives invited to witness the weird wedding decked out in frightening garb. Only the minister who performed the ceremony came in regular attire. Hutcherson said she had to talk her beloved into the unusual wedding. ``I was kind of leery at first,'' said Taylor, 34. ``But I'd rather be married to Debra in costume than not at all.'' Another couple in Evansville, Ind., had the same idea Saturday. Stephanie Plemmons, resplendent in her white dress, makeup and Frankenstein-head earrings, married Glen Hettenbach, attired in green makeup and with bolts attached to his neck. Eerie music played as the ceremony started and thunder crashed when the couple kissed. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Police caught the devil and tossed him in the cooler. An inebriated party-goer dressed like the devil was arrested while driving home from a Halloween celebration early Sunday. Police Sgt. Mike Pattee said the man, whose name was withheld, had a blood-alcohol content of .15 percent, nearly twice the legal limit of .08 percent. The man was among 246 people arrested for drunken driving during a weekend crackdown that ended early Sunday. About 65 Los Angeles Police Department and California Highway Patrol officers patrolled streets and freeways as a part of the operation. ``We're getting ready for the holiday season,'' Pattee said. ---- CENTREVILLE, Md. (AP) - This town's former jail is being converted for the ``Haunted Crack House II: The Horror of Using Drugs Continues,'' the sequel to last year's frightening look at the dangers of drug use. The original Haunted Crack House was the brainchild of John L. Lechliter, then the town's police chief. It drew 2,800 visitors and national attention. Haunted Crack House II takes visitors along on the drug odyssey of ``Liz,'' a young mother who craves crack, a potent form of cocaine, so much that it finally kills her and her baby. Visitors watch officers ``arrest'' Liz on the street outside the three-story, 82-year-old brick building. Then they follow her story through 14 rooms to court, her family's living room (where her parents aren't listening), a teen-age drug party, jail, and eventually morgue, funeral home and cemetery. About 200 volunteers will work to make the evening as spooky and informative as possible.

DOC.HEAD: Presidential Brawl Threatens Stability of Irish Government
DOC.TEXT: The first presidential race in 17 years could bring down the government and give Ireland its first woman president - in large part because one candidate can't decide whether he made a telephone call eight years ago. Because of the controversy, the government faces a vote of confidence on Wednesday, one week before the presidential election. Defense Minister Brian Lenihan, the early front-runner in the campaign, has stumbled on his varying recollections of a telephone call to President Patrick Hillery in 1982. In the alleged phone call - which followed a no-confidence vote in parliament - Lenihan reportedly improperly pressured the president to ask the opposition party to form a government - instead of calling national elections. In May, Lenihan, who is also deputy prime minister, said he ``distinctly'' remembered the call. But when the issue came up last week, Lenihan denied making the call. He kept denying it even after the whole country heard a tape recording of him discussing the call in detail with a political science student. ``On mature recollection, and full reflection, I did not ring President Hillery on that night,'' Lenihan said Thursday night after the tape was broadcast. The Irish Times on Friday carried a cartoon of a tape cassette with the caption: ``Sure, weren't we told all along that Brian was a sound man. ...'' Overnight, Ireland's bookies named Mary Robinson the favorite to win the presidential election. ``The people of Ireland will be surprised and dismayed that a person can deny so emphatically what he said last May,'' said Mrs. Robinson, who had been 17 points behind Lenihan in an Irish Times poll published on Oct. 10. A poll published Sunday by the Sunday Independent, based on 500 voters in the Dublin area, showed Mrs. Robinson with 51 percent support to Lenihan's 32 percent. That poll gave no indication, however, of how opinion was moving in the rural bases of Fianna Fail, Lenihan's party. Following the broadcast of the tape, opposition parties filed motions of no confidence in the government of Prime Minister Charles Haughey. The fate of the coalition government, which has a one-vote majority, hinges on the six members of the junior partner, the Progressive Democrats. The presidential election is a rarity in Ireland. Hillery, nearing the end of his second seven-year term, was simply nominated by agreement of the major parties. Mrs. Robinson, who has the support of the Labor Party and the socialist Workers Party but belongs to neither, is a former senator who in the past has taken controversial positions in favor of legalizing divorce and contraception. The third candidate, Austin Currie, made his reputation in the Roman Catholic civil rights movement in British-ruled Northern Ireland. He was elected to the Dail, Ireland's parliament, last year. Appearing on a broadcast with Lenihan on Monday, former Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald said Lenihan, Haughey and other Fianna Fail leaders put improper pressure on Hillery in 1982 after FitzGerald's government lost the vote of confidence. Haughey, according to FitzGerald, wanted the president to ask Fianna Fail to form a government without having a national election. Haughey has denied approaching Hillery. The alleged calls raise a fine point of law and custom: whether the opposition may advise the president in exercising his one real power, the right to dissolve parliament. In an interview in May with Jim Duffy, a graduate student in political science at University College, Dublin, Lenihan said he clearly remembered telephoning Hillery. ``I remember talking to him and he wanted to lay off. There was no doubt about it in his mind; in fact, looking back on it, it was a mistake on our part ...'' said Lenihan, who also holds the title of Tanaiste, or deputy prime minister. He said that Hillery, a Fianna Fail man himself, ``was annoyed with the whole bloody lot of us.''

DOC.HEAD: Five Soldiers Sentenced for Abusing Arab Detainee
With AM-Israel, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A military tribunal sentenced five Israeli soldiers to jail Sunday and stripped them of their rank for abusing an Arab detainee and threatening to execute him, Israel radio reported. Israeli security forces have come under close scrutiny amid international criticism of Israel over the Oct. 8 killings of 20 Palestinians on the Temple Mount. The highest-ranking officer sentenced Sunday was Sgt. Menachem Zemach, who was ordered jailed for two months, the radio said. The judges reportedly ruled that Zemach and his troops of the armored corps pretended to execute a blindfolded and bound 19-year-old detainee in July. They put the detainee, Anis Zaidan of Beitin village in the occupied West Bank, through a fake lie detector test and ``smoothed a knife over his cheek and forehead,'' saying he was to be executed, the radio said. One of the troopers later kicked Zaidan in the back so hard that he fainted, the radio said. It said Zaidan was released when he awoke. Zaidan was detained when the soldiers,searching his home, found pro-PLO slogans daubed on the roof, the radio said. The other four soldiers received sentences of 14 days to three months, and all were demoted from the ranks of sgt. or corpl. to private, the radio said. The military command declined comment. In another trial, a commander stationed in Nablus in the early days of the 34-month-old Palestinian uprising reportedly said that then-Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin had ordered troops to break the bones of Arab stone-throwers. Rabin has repeatedly denied giving such orders and has said he permitted soldiers to beat Palestinians only during a riot or if a suspect resisted arrest. But a border police comander, Moshe Viltzig, gave a different version before a tribunal in Tel Aviv, Israel radio said. Viltzig testified at the trial of Yehuda Meir, a former commander in Nablus indicted for ordering soldiers to break the bones of rioters in January 1988. Viltzig said he heard Rabin tell a closed meeting of commanders that Palestinians detained in stone-throwing riots should be beaten as punishment, the radio said.

DOC.HEAD: Police Say Couple Steals Sunglasses, Sells on Blackmarket
DOC.TEXT: A couple have been charged with stealing designer sunglasses in the United States as part of a scheme to sell them on the Soviet black market, police said. The two are believed to be part of a group that steals glasses to sell in the Soviet Union at three times their U.S. retail value, police said. Police said they confiscated about 60 display case keys and a notebook containing addresses of optical stores in New York City, eastern Pennsylvania and New Jersey. Eduard Fridman, 32, and Victoria Feldmus, 30, of New York City, were arrested Friday for stealing four pairs of sunglasses worth $996 from a Fort Lee store, Englewood Cliffs police Capt. George Kirschbaum said. The two were being held in lieu of $6,500 bail each on charges of shoplifting and possession of stolen goods, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Rebels Hold Talks with Dissident Military Officers
DOC.TEXT: Communist insurgents have met with dissident military officers to discuss an alliance against the government of President Corazon Aquino, the rebel leaders said. In an interview with The Associated Press, a group of Communist officials confirmed newspaper reports that they had met members of the clandestine Young Officers' Union, which helped stage a coup attempt in December. In Saturday's interview, the officials said the ``essentially exploratory'' talks were held twice last week before a leftist-called general strike. But they denied claims by the military that leftist and rightist extremists had cooperated in violence during the strike, called to force the government to increase the minimum wage. The talks were initiated by the leaders of the Young Officers' Union, said Sergio Romero, chief of the Alex Boncayao Brigade, the Manila wing of the Communist New People's Army. The name is an alias. Maj. Abraham Purugganan, a leader of the Young Officers, claimed in reports Monday his group was joining the rebels for a ``nationalist revolution'' to oust Mrs. Aquino and establish a federal system of government with a one-house legislature. ``On our part, we are always open to alliances, but the basis of unity should always be clear,'' said Martin Serrano, Manila area Communist Party secretary. ``What we want is for them to declare their program or what they are fighting for, not to us but to the people.'' ``If this program approximates our own anti-imperialist, anti-feudal and anti-fascist national democratic program, we don't see any reason why there should be no unity,'' Serrano said. Juan Liwanag, a leader of the National Democratic Front, an umbrella group headed by Communists, said the dissident officers would have to clarify their goals before the leftist groups trusted them enough to form an alliance. While some of the rebellious officers in the country proclaim democratic goals, others are seen as favoring military dictatorship. The Communist party and its New People's Army have been waging an insurgency for 21 years to establish a Marxist government in the Philippines.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Says Talks in Baghdad Not Fruitful
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with Shevardnadze saying talks in Baghdad unsuccessful, details of Mitterrand-Gorbachev talks, accords. No Pickup
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet envoy to Iraq appears to have failed in his effort to find a peaceful way out of the Persian Gulf crisis, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze said Sunday night. ``For the moment, there are not many reasons for optimism'' coming from Yevgeny Primakov's talks with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, Shevardnadze said during his visit to Paris with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev. Shevardnadze did not elaborate, but said he was still hopeful for a peaceful resolution of the crisis that began when Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Soviet diplomats Saturday postponed a U.N. Security Council resolution because they said its harsh condemnation of Iraq could tie Primakov's hands as he entered the talks Sunday with Saddam. Gorbachev had said Saddam seemed to be softening his stance on Kuwait. Shevardnadze made his brief comments while attending a signing ceremony for five scientific and economic agreements between French and Soviet officials and academics. During an visit earlier to Spain, Gorbachev and Shevardnadze suggested there were still ways to achieve a peaceful resolution to the gulf crisis. ``It is necessary to find such a path to a political solution, but it is difficult to know what it is,'' Shevardnadze said in Barcelona on Sunday. Gorbachev and French President Francois Mitterrand met over dinner Sunday and discussed the gulf crisis and next month's conference on European security, a French spokesman said. The two leaders said the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, which opens in Paris on Nov. 19, presents ``a unique occasion to bring together all the countries concerned to crown this year of change in Europe,'' spokesman Hubert Vedrine said. Gorbachev arrived in Paris on Sunday evening for an overnight visit on his way home from the three-day trip to Spain. He was met at the airport by Mitterrand, who just arrived from a summit of European leaders in Rome. France and the Soviet Union are set to sign a Treaty of Understanding and Cooperation that will increase cooperation between the two states in energy, non-military nuclear science, transportation, high-definition television and telecommunications. Vedrine last week called the pact ``very ambitious, and unprecedented in Franco-Soviet relations.'' The visit to Spain was packed with ceremonies honoring the Gorbachev on his first trip abroad since winning the Nobel Peace Prize earlier this month. Both Gorbachev and his wife Raisa took advantage of opportunities to plunge into the crowds that came to see them. The architect of perestroika, or openness, also found time to win $1.5 billion in Spanish guaranteed loans to help ease his country's painful transition to a market economy. Among the agreements signed in France on Sunday was one providing $1 billion in loans and credits to the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Reports: Coalition Government To Resign Over EEC Split
DOC.TEXT: Norway's year-old coalition government will resign Monday after failing to resolve a split over trade negotiations with the European Economic Community, news reports said Sunday. Government sources refused to confirm the reports, but a brief news release from the office of Conservative Prime Minister Jan P. Syse said a statement would be issued in Parliament on Monday. There is disagreement in the three-party alliance over Norway's position on talks between the 12-nation EEC and the European Free Trade Association, in which Norway and five other nations are members. The two trade blocs are discussing possibly opening all 18 nations to unrestricted trade after 1992. Syse's Conservative Party favors the alliance, but the Center Party, the smallest coalition partner, opposes ECC membership for Norway or broad changes in Norwegian laws that limit foreign access to natural resources and ownership in domestic industries. Syse reportedly spent the weekend trying to salvage the Conservative-dominated coalition, which also includes Christian Democrats. The Conservatives have previously said they would not allow the coalition to stall the talks. Conservative parliamentary leader Anders Talleraas said ``chances are extremely small'' a compromise between the two parties could be reached before parliament's debate on the issue, scheduled for Monday. The state television network NRK and the national news agency NTB reported Syse would resign, but it was not immediately clear who would form a new government. Syse could propose a single-party Conservative government or a new coalition. He could also ask former Prime Minister Gro Harlem Brundtland of the Labor Party to form her third socialist government since 1981. Norway's constitution does not allow for dissolving parliament and calling new elections. When the coalition toppled Ms. Brundtland last October, it left the EEC issue vague. ``What has happened is that the basic difference between the Conservatives and the Center has now come out in full bloom,'' said Anne Enger Lahnstein, Center's parliamentary leader. The Geneva-based free trade association includes Austria, Finland, Iceland, Norway, Sweden and Switzerland. Present trade agreements with the EEC are mostly limited to industrial goods. The EEC members are Belgium, Denmark, France, West Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Britain, Spain and Portugal. The nations aim to integrate their economies and coordinate social developments.

DOC.HEAD: Nationalists and Socialists Lead Elections in Basque Region
DOC.TEXT: A coalition of Basque nationalists and Socialists that has governed the fractious Basque region since 1986 appeared headed for another term, based on early returns from regional elections Sunday. There were no reports of violence, in contrast to three previous Basque regional elections since the region was given home rule in 1980. An exit poll made public by Spanish National Radio and Television immediately after the polls closed at 8 p.m. gave the Basque Nationalist Party about 25 percent of the vote, making it the strongest single political group. Based on that popular vote, the Nationalists would gain 21 to 24 seats in the 75-member parliament. That would mark a big increase over the 17 they had held since the November 1986 election. It appeared likely the Nationalists would form a coalition once again with the Socialists, this time with the Nationalists as senior partner. The Socialists, who run the national government, were projected to receive 17 percent of the vote and take 15 to 18 seats, down from the 19 they won in 1986. The radical Basque party Herri Batasuna, considered to be the political arm of the terrorist group ETA, was projected to remain the third political force in the Basque country with 17 percent of the vote and 12 to 14 seats. Herri Batasuna is the only Basque party that did not subscribe to a 1987 pact renouncing political violence. ETA stands for homeland and liberty in the Basque language. The group seeks independence for the three-province region. Since 1968, its attacks have claimed more than 600 lives, including 15 this year. The turnout among the region's 1.7 million eligible voters was estimated at 54 percent, the lowest in the Basque country since Spain returned to democracy in 1977. Two other nationalist parties, the center-left Eusko Alkartasuna, and the leftist Euskadiko Ezkerra, were projected to win 11 and 10 percent of the vote respectively, slightly less than their totals in the 1986 vote. The conservative Popular Party, the main opposition party in the national parliament, increased its presence from two seats to at least five, the projection showed. Unidad Alavesa, another nationalist group splintered from the Popular Party, was projected to make its parliamentary debut with one to three seats. The projection, by the Metra-6 polling agency, was based on interviews with 20,000 voters at 85 voting stations.

DOC.HEAD: Inmates Remain In Lockdown Following Riot
DOC.TEXT: Suspected ringleaders were in isolation Sunday after a riot in which several hundred black and Hispanic inmates battled each other with rocks and weightlifting equipment. One inmate was in critical condition and about 800 inmates were confined in dormitory-style rooms, said officials of Chuckawalla Valley State Prison, a medium-security facility 200 miles east of Los Angeles. Officials said 30 suspected ringleaders were sequestered in a room separate from the other inmates. Warden Bob Briggs said the lockdown affected the ``D'' section only. Operations were normal at the rest of the prison. Inmates under lockdown still were allowed visitors, but were escorted to the visitors section and visits were limited to two hours, Briggs said. At least 300 inmates began brawling outside the dormitory early Saturday, apparently in a dispute over access to telephones. ``Two groups went at it with anything they could get,'' Briggs said. ``They put rocks in their socks. It was pretty much anything you could grab. It was a riotous condition, but not a riot in the sense they were trying to take over the prison.'' Fifteen inmates were injured and guards fired warning shots to break up the melee. No one was struck by the gunfire and no guards were injured. Briggs said the D-section lockdown would continue at least until Monday. ``Because of the racial overtones we'll have to be sure we're on very good grounds before we stop,'' he said. ``We'll have to be sure the hard feelings are down.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Say Teen-Ager Went on Stabbing Spree at State Fair
DOC.TEXT: A teen-age girl has been booked on four counts of attempted murder after allegedly going on a stabbing spree on the midway of the Louisiana State Fair. The stabbings of four teen-age girls late Saturday apparently grew out of an earlier squabble between two groups of suspected gang members, police said. Police recovered a knife with a roughly 5-inch blade at the scene. Carolyn Burnham, 16, of Shreveport was apprehended outside the fair grounds and booked into the city jail Saturday night, police said. Police said she was with one group of suspected gang members and the victims were with another group. At least two of the victims, all from Shreveport, were in serious condition, one with a collapsed lung, at LSU Medical Center late Saturday. Officials would not give out their conditions Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Benton's Final Work Back in Nashville
DOC.TEXT: Artist Thomas Hart Benton's mural ``The Sources of Country Music'' has returned home following a two-year, nine-city tour of American museums. Benton's mural is back on display at the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum. It was commissioned in 1974 by the Country Music Foundation, which operates the museum, and was completed the following year. The mural is a 6-foot-by-10-foot canvas featuring near life-sized figures depicting the major musical and cultural traditions that helped shape the sound of modern country music. Figures in the painting include a dulcimer player, fiddlers, hymn singers, square dancers, a banjo player, a singing cowboy, a train and a river boat. The mural went on tour during the 100th anniversary of Benton's birth in 1889. Benton died in 1975. ``This great painting links a wonderful artist with an important subject: the folk roots of country music,'' said Jim Foglesong, chairman of the board of the Country Music Foundation.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinians Back to Work After Four-Day Ban
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 4 grafs after 7th graf pvs, `I hope...,' to ADD report of opposition to opening borders; pickup 8th graf pvs, `Tel Aviv....' SUBS 6 grafs for 29-31 pvs bgng ```The police...' to UPDATE with new unrest; no pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos JRL1,TLV1,2
DOC.TEXT: Most Palestinians returned to work in Israel Sunday after a four-day ban, but some found they had lost their jobs to Jews and others were turned back at roadblocks. Police had new orders barring Arabs with a record of hostile activity against Israel. About 8,000 Palestinians carry green identity cards that ban them from Israel as security risks, according to the daily Haaretz. ``We will increase the list of those not allowed into Israel,'' Shmuel Goren, government coordinator in the territories, said on Israel radio. The Cabinet, meanwhile, left its police minister to decide the fate of senior police officers criticized by an official inquiry into the Oct. 8 killings of 20 Palestinians. The killings on Jerusalem's hallowed Temple Mount prompted a wave of Arab-Jewish clashes inside Israel, leading to the four-day closure of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. The closure was lifted Sunday. But Defense Minister Moshe Arens warned he might reimpose it if violence continues. ``I hope we won't have to take such a step,'' he said on army radio.``There are tens of thousands who work in Israel who are trustworthy ... and we want to allow them to make an honorable living.'' Some Israeli Cabinet ministers argued against lifting the closure, saying the atmosphere is still too tense, Israeli radio and television reported. ``The closure wasn't to punish the Palestinians, but to restore calm and a sense of security. These aims, in my opinion, haven't been achieved yet,'' Transport Minister Moshe Katsav said. During a memorial for three Israeli stabbing victims, some Jewish extremists demanded a permanent ban on Arab labor from the occupied lands. ``Suddenly the gates were reopened so the murderers could come to our houses, why?'' legislator Rehavam Zeevi of the ultra right-wing Moledet Party told the gathering. Tel Aviv car wash owner Nissim Ahbari said he hired two recently discharged Israeli soldiers while his Arab worker was confined to the Gaza Strip. ``I prefer that Jews work instead of Arabs,'' he said. ``I am ready to pay them more money. These guys are getting 15 shekels ($7.50) more a day than the Arabs got.'' A Jerusalem restaurant owner, however, said his hired Jewish replacements were temporary. He said his Arab workers had been with him for 17 years and were like family. An Arab construction laborer in east Jerusalem said most of his friends were looking for other jobs. ``There is always work, but the situation is different now. There is a lot of fear and everyone is tense,'' he said on Israel radio, without giving his name. Three Jews were killed in Arab attacks, and two Arabs were killed by Jews in the random violence that prompted Wednesday's closure. Israel radio said the attacks fueled a wave of applications by Israelis for weapons licenses, most of which were rejected by the Interior Ministry. Up to 150,000 of the 1.7 million Palestinians in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip have jobs in Israel, mostly as blue-collar workers. The closure was welcomed in Israel, with many Jews saying it would vacate jobs for unemployed Israelis and Soviet Jewish immigrants, as well as free Israel from its dependence on Arab labor. The Education Ministry approved a special school schedule for children in farming villages to give them a day on which to help with work usually done by Arabs. Some Palestinians also welcomed the closure, saying that forcing Arabs to fend for themselves could be a step toward an independent Palestinian economy. Although most Arabs returned to their jobs Sunday, it was unclear how many would be affected by the new security restrictions, which included tightening the ban on overnight stays in Israel, the government said. Such stays are illegal, but the ban is widely ignored. At the entrance from Gaza to Israel, soldiers ordered every driver to open the trunk of his car, and the contents were searched. A man with two blankets in his car was told to take them home. ``We are doing this in an attempt to make sure that they aren't able to sleep in Israel,'' a soldier explained on condition of anonymity. The Cabinet, meanwhile, said it accepted the conclusions of the three-man investigative team appointed by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir. The panel said the shooting at the Mount, known in Arabic as Haram es-Sharif, was in self-defense but chastised senior police officers for failing to prepare for violence and being absent when it began. Police killed 20 Palestinians and injured 140 after Arab protesters threw rocks at Jews praying below at the Western Wall. ``What we decided was to accept the report of the commission and to allow the minister responsible to implement those parts which need to be carried out,'' Health Minister Ehud Olmert said after Sunday's session.
